rulebook-musician.title: Musician
rulebook-musician.def:
Musician is a unit-wide upgrade, normally represented by the presence of a regimental musician.

When performing a Reform Move or Combat Reform, a unit containing a Musician may change the number of its files by 4 rather than the normal 2.

Remember that Musician also interacts with the ability of Light Troops to make Reform Moves.

rulebook-duplicate_model_rules.title: Duplicate Model Rules
rulebook-duplicate_model_rules.def:
Most Model Rules are not cumulative. This means that if a model gains the same rule multiple times, the effects do not stack or provide extra benefits.
This includes Model Rules with different keywords attached (such as Multiple Wounds(towards Height 2) and Multiple Wounds(towards Height 3)), which are considered to be the same Model Rule, meaning that both instances cannot be applied simultaneously.

In such cases, the owner may choose which instance of the Model Rule to use at any time.

rulebook-model_rules_and_units.title: Model Rules and Units
rulebook-model_rules_and_units.def:
Even though Model Rules are given to individual models, some of them function on a unit level, such as those dictating how entire units can move or operate.
Model Rules differentiate between the following cases (The same keywords also apply to Properties):


  • Units entirely with X: whenever a Model Rule is referred to as units entirely with the rule, this refers to units where every single model in it has the Rule X or the Property X.

  • Units containing X: whenever a Model Rule is referred to as units containing the rule, this refers to units where at least one model in it has the Rule X or the Property X.

  • Units not containing X: whenever a Model Rule is referred to as units not containing the rule, this refers to units where no single model in it has the Rule X or the Property X.

rulebook-attack_attributes.title: Attack Attributes
rulebook-attack_attributes.def:
Attack Attributes is a subcategory of Model Rules.

While most Model Rules apply to the entire model (including all model parts on the same base), Attack Attributes are an exception, and only affect individual model parts, or even individual attacks.
Attack Attributes only affect Melee Attacks, unless otherwise stated.

There is one main exception to this: an Attack Attribute given specifically to a weapon, a spell or attack will affects it regardless of whether it would normally only be applicable to Melee Attacks.


Attack Attributes are therefore written under the Offensive Characteristics part of a model entry, only affecting the specific model part they are listed under.

However, if an Attack Attribute is given to a unit (e.g. as a result of a spell), it applies to every model part in that unit; if given to a model, it applies to all parts of that model.

An Attack Attribute can also be given to a weapon, a spell, or an attack. Such Attack Attributes only affect attacks made with those specific sources. They will not affect other attacks made by the same model part (unless given specifically to another weapon, spell or attack by that model part).

rulebook-keywords.title: Keywords
rulebook-keywords.def:
Model Rules include keywords to help define their effects.

These keywords can be used directly within the Rulebook, and always apply to rules that have that keyword.

Alternatively, keywords can be specified for individual rules on specific models, spells, or weapons. In this case, this is indicated within brackets following the name of the rule.

List of Model Rule keywords:


  • Cumulative: effects from multiple instances of a Model Rule with the Cumulative keyword are combined and add up.

  • Distance Modifiers: written as a number followed by the " symbol. Any distance in the Model Rule description is replaced by that number.

For example, Vanguard(3"") means that the model can perform a Vanguard move, but its Mobility is set to 3" instead of the normal 6".

  • Shooting or Melee & Shooting: an Attack Attribute with the keyword Shooting only affects attacks that the model part makes with Shooting Weapons, while an Attack Attribute with the keyword Melee & Shooting affects both Melee Attacks and Shooting Attacks made by the model part.


  • Remember that the default if none of these keywords are used is that Attack Attributes only affect Melee Attacks.

For example, by default, Poison Attacks only affect Melee Attacks. However, if a model part has Poison Attacks(Shooting), this means the Poison Attacks Model Rule only applies to attacks made with that model part’s Shooting Weapons, unless it also has Poison Attacks or Poison Attacks(Melee & Shooting).



  • Special Attacks: a model part with such a rule can make a special Melee Attack (which is not a Standard Melee Attack) that hits automatically.

Since it is not a Standard Melee Attack, this attack can usually not be made as a Supporting Attack and does not suffer from Restricted Attacks (see the Melee Phase chapter).

Special Attacks cannot be allocated towards Attachable Models that could not be the target of a Ranged Attack (see the Attacks chapter).

  • Towards X: the Attack Attribute only applies if the attack is allocated to a specific type of enemy model or an enemy model that has certain rules or Properties.

The conditions are given as X. If more than one type of enemy is relevant, those types are separated by the word or. If multiple conditions must be fulfilled simultaneously, then they are separated by the word and.

For example, Multiple Wounds(2, towards Height 4 and Beast, or Height 5) means that the rule Multiple Wounds is applied only when the attack is allocated either to a model that is both Height 4 and has the Property Beast, or to a model that is of Height 5, regardless of whether the model has the Property Beast.

  • Against X: the Model Rule only applies when the model is attacked by a certain type of model or by a model or attack with certain rules or Properties.

For example, Hard Target(against Lethal Strike) means that the rule Hard Target applies only when the model is attacked by an attack with the Attribute Lethal Strike. See the rules under Towards X for how to interpret the words or and and.

  • Unique Keywords: in addition to the standard Model Rule keywords defined above, certain Model Rules have unique keywords. These are defined in their respective rules.

rulebook-introduction.def:
Welcome to the tabletop wargame known as The 9th Age: Fantasy Battles, or T9A for short. This is a community crafted miniatures wargame, where grand armies collide in monumental conflicts for supremacy and survival. The game is played on a tabletop with terrain features and miniatures to represent the battlefield and the clashing armies, and it uses six-sided dice and measuring devices to move miniatures and resolve actions such as charging into battle, letting arrows loose, and casting spells.

For all the rules, feedback, and suggestions, please visit our webpage: the-ninth-age.com. The rules presented in this book are considered the Core Rules of T9A and are used in all T9A games.\
Licence: Copyright Creative Commons

Rules representation

In order to keep rules clear and tidy, the following text formatting is used:

Text in a grey box denotes designer notes. In these are the designers giving some insights into intent behind rules, alternate ways to play the game, or shortcuts to speed things up.

  • CAPITALIZATION is used for words/phrases that are defined in this book, such as Round of Combat, unless they are common words with no elaborate game definition like model or unit, but Combat is since it is not used like the common British term.

  • Bold font or text is used to highlight specific words. It is also used in Army Books to emphasise Model Rules specified in the same unit entry.

  • Italic font marks reminders, examples, clarifications, and other content that are not direct rules.

  • Grey-coloured text is used for figure and table captions, item restrictions, repetitive content, and Properties, which is a special type of keyword that doesn’t transfer any direct rules.

  • Hyperlinks can be found in the electronic version of this document, and the page footer includes hyperlinks to key sections.

  • Pink text is unique to the Reference Handbook .

This Handbook covers corner-cases and specific circumstances that are not expected to be relevant in the majority of games.

The Handbook is a copy of the Illustrated Rulebook with additional sections added to cover these corner-cases.

Rules Documents

Illustrated Rulebook

The Illustrated Rulebook contains a streamlined version of the main rules needed for playing the game, alongside art, miniature images and lore.
Appendices

Appendices are an integral component of the core rules, and are used in most games. There are two appendices to the Illustrated Rulebook:

  • Illustrated Rulebook – Appendix I: Model Rules -- Additional and unique rules that specific models possess.

  • Illustrated Rulebook – Appendix II: Arcane Compendium -- The compendium contains spells from the ten different Paths of Magic, along with the common Magic Items and special Leadership Skills.

Season Pack

This document includes additional Deployment Types, maps, Primary and Secondary Objectives, catering towards more advanced games.

Reference Handbook

This handbook includes all rules from the Illustrated Rulebook, plus Appendix I: Model Rules and Appendix II: Arcane Compendium documents.

Additionally, it includes extended rules text to cover for intricate and complex battlefield situations. We recommend that players who prefer to understand complex situations in advance and fully grasp the nuances of all rule interactions turn directly to this document.

For new players and those who prefer to deal with intricate scenarios as they arise, we suggest starting with the Illustrated Rulebook and only consulting the Reference Handbook when specific situations occur that are not fully covered in the Illustrated Rulebook.

This document is the Illustrated Rulebook, containing a streamlined version of the main rules needed for playing the game alongside art, miniature images and lore. In addition to this, you will need a few more documents to play a full game of T9A.\
Army Books

The rules for the different armies are found in Army Books. Within these, you will find army composition rules, unit and model rules, characteristics, and so on.

Supplements

Supplements are optional add-ons to the game that require an agreement with the opponent before using.

It is the tenth century of the Ninth Age. An Age of Peace, they say. An Age of Respite. An Age of Exploration and Rebuilding, following the many Ages of Ruin and the great Inferno.

And yet everywhere, the shadow of war looms.

The peoples of the world have rebuilt, indeed: perhaps too far, with too much ambition.

They must contend with elder powers of elves and dwarves who have regained their former glory. With so-called barbarian tribes of ogres, orcs, goblins and beasts herds, who display a strength and hunger for battle like never before. With ancient necromantic dynasties reawoken, with renewed cabals of scheming Night Lords, with the devotees of Dark Gods flocking in ever-greater numbers, ushering otherworldly servants from beyond the Veil. With strange species of reptiles and rodents, long thought extinct, threatening a return to ancient empires of enslavement.

And finally, they must contend with humanity itself, which has perhaps grown the most of all. Since the coming of the legendary hero Sunna, it has developed from primitive tribes into mighty nations whose will to conquer knows no bounds.

It is an Age of Promise. An Age of Possibility. An age where everything is to play for. Where any of the world’s powers could soon become master of all others. Where the world itself holds its breath. No longer an Age of Peace: it has become an Age of Battle.
rulebook-introduction.title: Introduction

rulebook-the_flow_of_the_game.def:
This game is divided into three main sections, performed in order.

1 - Battle Preparations. Before a game, certain preparations are needed.
The players need to put together their armies, prepare the battlefield, agree on Victory Conditions and Deploy their armies.

2 - Game Turns. The 9th Age is a turn-based game played over six Game Turns.
Each Game Turn consists of two Player Turns.
These are made up of a series of Phases:

  • Charge Phase

  • Movement Phase

  • Magic Phase

  • Shooting Phase

  • Rally Phase

  • Melee Phase

3 - After the Game. After both players have played their six Player Turns, it is time to tally up the Victory Points and check who managed to complete the Primary and Secondary Objectives to determine who is the winner of the game.


Greeeetings! I am Klepa, one hundred percent honest and reliable merchant goblin. This is my healthful and fine-smelling accomplice – ah – pet! my charming pet: Fleabag. For smallest of prices, and promise not to talk to mean old city guards, we can be your guides here. Klepa will share all his, er, lawfully ack-quee-zis-shined knowledge about the wide world of the Ninth Age! Such a pleasure to meet a new mark – I mean customer! Customer and friend! Welcome

Active & Reactive Player


The Active Player is the one currently taking their Player Turn, and the Reactive Player is the one whose Player Turn is not currently happening.\\
Before the first Player Turn, the Defender is the Active Player.

Friendly and Enemy

The terms friendly and enemy are used to distinguish between units, model, spells, and other effects belonging to the same player (friendly) and units, models, spells, and other effects controlled by the opposing player (enemy).

Your First Game


Is this your first game? Let’s get you started. First, prepare your battlefield: a large flat surface with model terrain on – a pile of books can be a hill, a mug can be a rock, a mouse pad can be a lake, and so on. Then, challenge a friend to a game where you both command your own miniature army.\\
For a trial run without the commitment of time and resources, we offer downloadable paper cutouts on the T9A website (Essence of War).


If you are uncertain about which army to choose, a brief overview of the 16 main armies and their primary themes can be found in the Introduction chapter.
rulebook-the_flow_of_the_game.title: The Flow of the Game

rulebook-battle_preparations.def:
Before battle can be joined, you must establish the nature of the battlefield, the armies that will fight upon it, and their reason for being there. This is a natural part of setting up the game, but it can also represent a commander reviewing their troops and scouting the land in preparation for an important battle.


When preparing to play a game of The 9th Age: Fantasy Battles, players follow a series of steps:

1 - Pre-game Planning usually done before players arrive to the gaming table

  • Decide Army Size, which determines the scale of the game. This can be done by the players agreeing on an Army Size, or an outside source such as campaign rules or a tournament organiser dictating this.

  • Build an Army. Each player creates an Army List from one of the Army Books.

2 - Initial Preparations these are sometimes done before arrival (typical in a tournament setting).

  • Build the Battlefield by setting up terrain and scenery to create an engaging and challenging environment for the battle.

  • Share Army Lists with your opponent, revealing the units and options you will be using during the game.

  • Determine Victory Conditions – normally this means picking Primary- and Secondary Objectives, which define the goals for the battle.

  • Determine Deployment Type – this defines where on the Battlefield the armies can start.


3 - Battle Setup (these actions are done at the gaming table by both players together)

  • Roll-off for Attacker and Defender: the players each roll a dice, the winner decides which player is going to be the Defender; the other will be the Attacker.

  • Defender Chooses a Deployment Zone, by deciding on which side of the table his army will start the game.

  • Pre-game Selections: these are choices made before Deployment.
Common choices include targets for Secondary Objectives and Spell Swaps.

  • Deploy units: both players place their units, starting with the Attacker, within their designated Deployment Zones.

  • Defender’s Advantage: the Defender gives Vanguard(3") to one of their units.

  • Move Vanguarding units: starting with the unit chosen as part of Defender’s Advantage, units that can do so perform their Vanguard Moves.


The Season Pack is an annually updated supplement that can provide support in building a battlefield and add several variations on Deployment Types, Primary Objectives and Secondary Objectives. If you are looking for a fast and simple game, or if this is one of your first games, we recommend you use the rules below and leave the Season Pack until next time.

/section{pregame_planning}/section{initial_preparations}/section{battle_setup}
rulebook-battle_preparations.title: Battle Preparations

rulebook-decide_army_size.def:
Before building an army, players need to agree on the scale of the battle, which corresponds to the chosen Army Size. Armies are then built so that the combined point costs of all their units does not exceed the designated Army Size, and is no less than than 50 points below that limit.

Army Size also determines the rules for army composition.

Points Cost


The Points Cost, often shortened pts, is a measure of the power of a unit or upgrade. We use points to ensure that two armies with a similar total Points Cost facing each other provide for a fair, balanced game experience.\
Every unit has a Points Cost, which is determined by adding its base cost with the cost of additional models added to it, as well as the cost of every additional option selected for that unit.
rulebook-decide_army_size.title: Decide Army Size

rulebook-build_an_army.def:
As the player, it is your duty to command your army on the battlefield, but first you will have to pick one of the different factions available to you. Each Army Book contains a description of the different units that are available to its faction, as well as their Characteristics and special rules.\
To build your army, you must write an Army List, which details the selection of units, spells and options you want to use, along with their Points Cost. Every unit, weapon, upgrade, and Magic Item has a specific Points Cost, which is used to balance the game and ensure fair play between the players.

Planning, strategy, knowing terrain, learning about the ponent – very useful for a heist! What? You were asking about battles? Oh yes, Klepa knows them too. We goblins are Warborn after all – that’s the name us and orc pals call ourselves together. Klepa has seen all the great battles, seen loads of action! Normally from quite far away – so you know I had a good view.
Main thing I’ve learned is you’ve got to get there early if you want the best spot for hiding and picking over the loot at the end. You want some loot? Genuine, authentikarated battle gear, picked from the choiciest corpses! Just step quietly over to Appendicitis Numero Two and we’ll have a little chat about the low low prices.


Army Books

The rules for playing the various factions are detailed in the Army Books and supplement Army Books (remember that using a supplement requires the agreement of your opponent or event organiser).

Unit Entries

Each entry in an Army Book belongs to a specific Army Category, represented by one or several specific icons in the Army Book. Each Army Category has its own Points Cost limit, as defined in the Army Book, determining how many Army Points a player can allocate to that particular category.
This allows players to create a balanced and strategic army composition for their games.





characterCharactersAn army can typically spend up to 40% of its Army Points on characters.

All entries in this Category follow the rules for both Characters and Attachable Models.Characters are the leaders and exceptional individuals in the army, wielding various skills such as brute force, tactical acumen, spellcasting ability, or engineering knowledge. They play a crucial role in influencing the outcome of battles, and one of them usually serves as the army’s General, responsible for leading and inspiring your forces.

coreCoreAn army must spend a minimum number of Army Points on this category generally 25%.

Core units represent the most readily available warriors in the faction, serving as essential rank-and-file troops under the command of the Characters. They are always present in some combination as part of your fighting force.

specialSpecialThis Army Category has no maximum limit. An army can spend any amount of Army Points on units in this Category.

The Special Army Category represents less common and more unique forces that are found in some but not all of your faction’s armies. While they might make up the largest portion of your host, the availability of each unit is still limited. They usually fill a range of useful and impactful roles.

EoSArmy-SpecificAn Army-Specific Category always has a maximum percentage of Army Points that can be spent on it; the limit is defined in the individual Army Books.

Army-Specific Categories introduce additional options and limitations in army building, reflecting the nature of the faction. Army-Specific Categories can include thematic groupings of units, limitations based on specific functions, and the faction’s most rare and powerful forces.

Units belonging to more than one Army Category

Some units can be included in more than one Army Category, which is represented by more than one icon in their entry. In these cases, simply count the unit’s Points Cost towards the limits of all its Army Categories, but only once towards the army’s Points Cost.

Adding Army Categories to a Unit

Choosing certain options can make a unit count towards another Army Category in addition to its original Army Category. For example, giving a unit Shooting Weapons might make it also count towards the Ranged Support Army Category.
This is marked by a small icon of the additional Army Category, displayed underneath the original Army Category icon(s), together with the conditions for counting towards this additional Army Category.

Splitting Point Cost between Army Categories

In a few cases, a unit’s Points Cost can be split between different Army Categories, where the Points Cost for some particular option is additionally counted towards a different Army Category than the unit. This is marked in the unit entry by a split icon, with the two halves representing the two Army Categories the unit counts towards.

For example, a 250 pts Elf Character, counted towards the Characters Army Category, decides to ride a 500 pts Dragon, which is an option marked to count additionally towards Beasts and Monsters. In this case, the player must count the entire unit’s Points Cost (250 + 500 = 750 pts) towards Characters, and the Dragon’s Points Cost (500 pts) towards Beasts and Monsters. Of course, only 750 pts are added towards the army’s total limit.

Rarity – Restrictions for Units and Items


All units and some options in the army have a limit on the number of times, that they can be included in the army.


  • Maximum Points Cost: unless mentioned otherwise a unit can cost no more that 600 Army Points. Some Unit Entries have a different maximum Points Cost, this replaces the general limit.
For example, a unit with (max. 800 pts) listed next to its unit size limits can cost up to 800 points instead of 600.


  • Max. X items per army: some items have an amount of Max. X allowed per army. Eg. Max. 20 bows, Max. 4 models. This means you can choose to include a maximum of X instances of each of these items in your army.

  • Regular: these Unit Entries are limited to a maximum of one per 500 Army Points (rounding fractions up).
For example, at 4000 Army Points, Regular Unit Entries are restricted to Max. 8/army).
Generally units taken from the Core Army Category are Regular.

  • Common: these items are limited to a maximum of one per 1000 Army Points (rounding fractions up).
For example, at 4000 Army Points, Common items are restricted to Max. 4/army).
This is the default limit for all Unit Entries.

  • Uncommon: these items are limited to a maximum of one per 1500 Army Points (rounding fractions up).
For example, at 4000 Army Points, Uncommon items are restricted to Max. 3/army).
This is the least restrictive limit generally used on magical items and unusual mounts.

  • Rare: these items are limited to a maximum of one per 2500 Army Points (rounding fractions up).
For example, at 4000 Army Points, Rare items are restricted to Max. 2/army).
Monsters, elite knights and powerful war machines usually follow this limit.

  • Extraordinary: these items are limited to a maximum of one per 5000 Army Points (rounding fractions up).
For example, at 4000 Army Points, Extraordinary items are restricted to Max. 1/army).
Army defining entries generally follow this limit, such as magical altars, faction unique upgrades and the most ancient of dragons.

  • Legendary: these items can only ever be taken once per army.

Most magic items, the Battle Standard Bearer and the general follow this limit.



  • Max. X combined items per army: some combinations of items may be restricted in combination. In these cases this will be detailed in the Army Organisation part of the Army Book.
This is usually units that can have a Character mounted on them or not, or it is a unit with a shooting and melee variant.

  • Max. X items per unit: some items have a maximum limitation allowed per unit. This means you can choose to include up to X instances of these items (mounts, upgrades, etc.) for each unit.


0.75orcKing.png

/subsubsection{spell_selection}
rulebook-build_an_army.title: Build an Army

rulebook-spell_selection.def:
Models that can cast spells of any kind are Casters.
Casters able to cast Learned Spells are also Wizards.

If a Caster has a choice between spells, or knows any Learned Spells, the chosen spells must be written on the Army List.

Casters know different numbers of spells, and select them as described in their unit entries, except for Wizards, who all follow the same general rules for selecting their Learned Spells:

Each of the following Wizard types must choose a Path of Magic to select spells from.
Which Paths it has access to is specified under each Wizard’s unit entry.
The chosen Path of Magic must be written on the Army List.

Wizards know a and can choose different Learned Spells them depending on their type:

  • Wizard Apprentice: 1 spell, that is the Apprentice Spell (#1).

  • Wizard Adept: 3 spells chosen from Apprentice Spell and Adept Spells (#1 – #4).

  • Wizard Master: 5 spells chosen from Apprentice Spell, Adept Spells, and Master Spells (#1 – #6).

If it is either of the following types, then the Wizard does not select a Path of Magic:

  • Wizard Conclave (X): X spells from the list of Learned Spells specified under its unit entry.

  • Protean Magic (X): X Apprentice Spells, chosen from any Path of Magic it has access to.

During Pre-game Selections, Casters may Swap Spells.

For details, see 3.2 Pre-game Selections.

To save time and space on Army List writing, we recommend that the Wizard level of a model is followed by the Path name with the numbers of the selected spells in brackets.

For example, Wizard Adept, Alchemy (2, 3, 4).
rulebook-spell_selection.title: Spell Selection

rulebook-community_tools.def:
To help with playing The 9th Age, we have a continually updated list of Community Tools.

These are all found on the T9A Download page and are free to use.

The most popular one at the release of 3.0 (and for a long time before then) is the online army builder tool New Recruit, developed by ‘Flammy’.

New Recruit is updated directly from the internal 9th Age files, so its point calculations are generally correct and updated with hardly any delay.

All tournament organisers are encouraged to use New Recruit, since the data collected from it are used by our teams to balance the game.

This balancing includes (but is not limited to) determining which units are potentially too popular or remain underused.

You can find it at this address: NewRecruit.eu

All community tools are available for free here: https://community.the-ninth-age.com/wcf/downloads/#communitysupportmaterial.
rulebook-community_tools.title: Community Tools

rulebook-share_army_lists.def:
After deciding on the scale of the game and writing their Army Lists, the next step is to share Army Lists and all relevant information about the upcoming game.

Sharing Army Lists before the game starts allows both players to look up the rules that apply to the units to be involved in the game, so that they understand how those will function and can plan their strategy accordingly, avoiding any unpleasant surprises, and minimising the time spent reading rules while playing.
rulebook-share_army_lists.title: Share Army Lists

rulebook-build_the_battlefield.def:
While the game is playable on a wide variety of of all dimensions, we recommend that the following sizes are adhered to.

This provides a good balance between enough room to manoeuvre your troops, without having so much room that there hardly any engagement happens.

  • Battlefield Size: the game is played on a rectangular Battlefield, with two main dimensions:

  • Short Table Edge: the main direction along which the two opposing armies face each other. We recommend this to be 48" (roughly 120 cm), regardless of Army Size.

  • Long Table Edge: in most Deployment Types, the long table edge is the side along which the units of each army is lined up. The bigger the armies are, the longer the table edge you need to fit all the units. See the table beside for recommendations.

  • Terrain placement: the terrain on the Battlefield is essential for adding depth and strategic elements to the game. It can represent various features, from simple objects to more significant landmarks.

Players have the flexibility to determine the size, type, and number of Terrain Features, as well as their placement.

Prebuilt Battlefield maps are available in the Season Pack.

Long Table Edge Short Table Edge Recommended Army Size
48" 48" 0 – 3499 pts Warband \
60" 48" 3500 – 3999 pts Field Army \
72" 48" 4000 – 4999 pts Field Army \
90" 48" 5000 – 6999 pts Field Army \
120" 48" 7000 – 9999 pts Grand Army


It’s not about winning, they say. Who is Klepa to disagreedy? Just a nice friendly battle with mounds of fallen comraddies – most important thing is to have fun with it! And whatever you do, don’t let the things you’ve seen haunt you the rest of your days!
rulebook-build_the_battlefield.title: Build the Battlefield

rulebook-determine_victory_conditions.def:
The Victory Conditions for the game are divided into three parts (see chapter After the Game for their relative importance):

  • Victory Points, representing how much of the opponent’s army has been removed as a casualty.

  • A single Primary Objective, that both players compete to win.

  • If using Secondary Objectives, one for each player see the Season Pack; if this is your first game, we recommend playing without Secondary Objectives.

If no outside source (e.g. tournament organiser, campaign rule, Season Packs…) tells you which Primary Objective to use, use the one below.

Scoring Units

Any Rank-and-File unit that fulfils all the conditions below is a Scoring Unit:

  • It has a Standard Bearer.

  • It does not have Light Troops.

  • It was not Summoned during the game.

  • It did not arrive on the Battlefield in Game Turn 6 (e.g. via Ambush).

A unit that is Shaken (see the Psychology chapter) temporarily stops being Scoring until it is no longer Shaken.

Rank-and-File Units

Any unit containing at least one Rank-and-File model (see Models and Units in the Definitions and Terminology chapter) is a Rank-and-File unit.



Primary Objective – Hold the Centre

Setup during Pre-game Selections: mark the Battlefield Centre.

Rules: END of Game Turns 3 to 6, the player with the most Scoring units within 9" of the Battlefield Centre gains a single Objective Counter.

End of Game Completion: the player with the most Objective Counters wins.
rulebook-determine_victory_conditions.title: Determine Victory Conditions

rulebook-determine_deployment_type.def:
If no outside source tells you what Deployment Type to use, players can use the Frontline Clash standard Deployment Type, or choose one from the Season Pack.

Frontline Clash

The Central line is the line drawn through the centre of the board and parallel to the Long Table Edges. Deployment Zones are more than 12" away from the Central Line, towards your Long Table Edge, and more than 6" from the Short Table Edges.

frontlineclash
Frontline Clash
The Central Line is the line drawn through the centre of the board and parallel to the Long Table Edges. Deployment Zones are more than 12" away from the Central Line, towards your Long Table Edge, and more than 6" from the Short Table Edges.
frontlineclash
rulebook-determine_deployment_type.title: Determine Deployment Type

rulebook-battle_setup.def:
3pt
Attacker Defender
Deployment Zone Chooses
Pre-game Selections Starts (all choices)
Deployment Phase 1st unit,unit,
…		 2nd unit,unit,
…
Defender’s Advantage Give one unit Vanguard(3")
Vanguard 2nd unit,unit,
…		 Defender’s Advantage choice,unit,
…

/subsection{rolloff_for_attacker_or_defender}/subsection{choosing_the_deployment_zone}/subsection{pregame_selections}/subsection{deploy_units}/subsection{defenders_advantage}/subsection{move_vanguarding_units}
rulebook-battle_setup.title: Battle setup

rulebook-rolloff_for_attacker_or_defende.def:
After determining Deployment Type and Victory Conditions, both players roll a D6 (a usual 6-sided dice, see Dice in the Definitions and Terminology chapter), rolling again until one player rolls higher.
The player who rolls the highest, decides which player will be the Defender; the other player will be the Attacker.
rulebook-rolloff_for_attacker_or_defende.title: Roll-off for Attacker or Defender

rulebook-pregame_selections.def:
The Defender now performs all their Pre-game Selections.

After this, the Attacker makes all their Pre-game Selections.

Spell Swapping

A common Pre-game Selection is for Casters to Swap Spells, using these following rules:

  • Hereditary Swap: every Wizard may replace one of its Learned Spells with the Hereditary Spell from its Army Book.

  • Universal Swap: a single Caster in your Army List may replace one of its chosen spells with another spell it could have chosen instead.

This does not let a Caster change the Path of Magic initially chosen during Spell Selection as part of Pre-game Planning, if the Caster did not select a Path of Magic, then this is not relevant.
rulebook-pregame_selections.title: Pre-game Selections

rulebook-deploy_units.def:
Starting with the Attacker, players then take turns Deploying their units fully inside their own Deployment Zone.

All units must follow the Unit Spacing rule (defined in the Definitions and Terminology chapter).

On each of their Deployment Turns, a player can Deploy any number of units, and must Deploy at least one unit.

Any Attachable Model that wishes to begin the game joined to a unit must be Deployed inside and simultaneously with that unit.

Once a player has Deployed their entire army, that player immediately chooses who has the first Player Turn.

Note: this entire army criteria does not include units that can, and choose to, be Deployed later during the game (such as units entirely with Ambush, Hidden).

Since finishing Deployment first allows you to choose which player has the first Player Turn, a common practice is to Deploy your entire army the first chance you get.

Once your are more comfortable with the game, you will start weighing the strategic benefits from knowing where the opponent’s troops are Deployed against the advantage of choosing who has the first Player Turn.

Rules and Abilities of Undeployed Units

Until being Deployed, units cannot perform any actions at all, and all their Magic Items, rules, and abilities not related to their Deployment are ignored, unless explicitly stated otherwise.

Undeployable Units

In the unlikely event that a unit cannot be Deployed during the Deployment Phase for whatever reason (e.g. if there is not enough space in the player’s Deployment Zone), it is removed as a casualty, unless specifically stated otherwise.
rulebook-deploy_units.title: Deploy Units

rulebook-defenders_advantage.def:
The Defender must choose a single of its Deployed units to gain Vanguard(3").

This unit cannot contain any Characters.

Note: a unit that already has Vanguard can still be chosen, the effects are just not cumulative.
rulebook-defenders_advantage.title: Defender’s Advantage

rulebook-move_vanguarding_units.def:
Now units entirely with Vanguard have a chance to perform their pre-game moves.

Starting with the unit that the Defender chose for Defender’s Advantage, the players alternate moving units one by one, until all units that can and want to make a Vanguard Move have done so.

Remember that per the Vanguard rule, no model can move further than 12", or end within 6" of an enemy unit. See Model Rules for further details.
rulebook-move_vanguarding_units.title: Move Vanguarding Units

rulebook-charge_phase.def:
In the Charge Phase, your forces will take the initiative, breaking from their ordered manoeuvres to run headlong across the field, with the single purpose of meeting the enemy in Combat. But such Charges are not so simple as they seem; eager troops can hesitate and stumble as the reality of battle approaches, or they might find their target is too far away, allowing the opponent to draw them out of position or rake them with fire before they can reach their ranks.The Charge Phase is an opportunity for the Active Player to move their units into Combat with enemy units by Declaring Charges.

It is the primary method of engaging in Close Combat.

Never wear red to a minotaur party – that’s one of the classic blunders!

The Charge Phase is divided into the following steps:

1 - Start of the Charge Phase (and Player Turn)
2 - Declare Charges

  • The Active Player chooses one of their units, and Declares a Charge towards an enemy unit.

  • The Reactive Player declares and resolves the target’s Charge Reaction.

  • Repeat steps (a) and (b) with your units, one at a time, until all of your units that can and wish to Declare a Charge have done so.

3 - Moves Charges

  • The Active Player chooses a unit that has Declared a Charge, and rolls its Charge Range roll.

If multiple units are charging the same target, make a separate Charge Range roll for every unit Charging the same target.

  • Perform the Charge Move or Failed Charge Move with the unit(s) you just rolled Charge Range for.

  • Repeat step 3 for all units that have Declared a Charge this Phase.

4 - End of the Charge Phase.


/section{declaring_charges}/section{charge_moves}/section{failed_charge_move}/section{engaged_in_combat}
rulebook-charge_phase.title: Charge Phase

rulebook-declaring_charges.def:
To Declare a Charge, select one of your units that has not already Declared a Charge this Phase, and that is not Engaged in Combat or Shaken.

Declare which enemy unit it will try to Charge, that fulfil all the following conditions:

  • The enemy unit must be in Line of Sight* of the Charging Unit.

  • It must be possible to complete the Charge towards the enemy unit.
I.e. the enemy unit must be within the Charging Unit’s maximum potential Charge Range, and there must be enough room to move the Charging Unit into Contact*.

*Line of Sight and Contact are both defined in the Definitions and Terminology chapter.

Only consider effects affecting the Charging Unit’s Charge Range that are present when the Charge is declared.

When determining if there is enough room for the Charging Unit, take into account already declared Charges, including Initial Align Moves of Charging Units.

Do not consider Flee! Charge Reactions, or potential casualties inflicted on the units.

Once a Charge is declared, the unit is considered to be Charging until one of the following occurs:

  • It has finished its First Round of Combat after making a Charge Move.

  • It performs a Failed Charge Move.

  • It is not Engaged in Combat.

So you’re getting charged. You screwed the pooch. You know the position you got yourself in is wrong. The question is, what’re you gonna do about it?
There’s an old saying among us goblins, real pearl of wisdom, what I would transeeliorate as “Always better to run away.” You know who doesn’t know that saying? Dead people. I mean lititerally! Those shufflers and groaners just don’t care. They’re already dead, see? What have they got to worry about? Something happens to them, they can just get back up again. That’s why you’ll never see a zombie running away from a fight.
Same goes for the spawn of the netherworld. Your average daemon don’t mind kicking the bucket, they only get poofed back into the other Realm. So they ain’t running scared neither. Course, being so nonch-allont about dying makes them even scarier for those of us who still have to bother about such cares and concerns. So you listen to your goblin pal: Always run away.

/subsection{charge_reactions}/subsection{charge_redirections}
rulebook-declaring_charges.title: Declaring Charges

rulebook-charge_reactions.def:
When a unit has a Charge declared against it, it must immediately perform a Charge Reaction.

The owner of the charged unit declares which Charge Reaction it chooses and resolve the effects immediately.

There are two Charge Reactions:

  • Hold! This is the default Charge Reaction.

Choosing the Hold! Charge Reaction means the unit stands its ground and takes no further action.

  • Flee! A unit can select this Charge Reaction only once per Phase, and only if not already Engaged in Combat.
The unit is pivoted to face directly away from the Centre of the Charging Unit; it then performs a Flee Move (see the Psychology chapter).

  • If this Flee Move brings the fleeing unit into contact with a unit that has Declared a Charge against it this Phase, the fleeing unit is immediately removed as a casualty.

  • Remember that Flee Moves due to the Flee! Charge Reaction, do not cause Panic Tests in friendly units that the Fleeing unit moves through since they are voluntary.

This does not apply if forced to Flee! due to being charged by a unit containing Terror.
rulebook-charge_reactions.title: Charge Reactions

rulebook-charge_redirections.def:
If a charged unit has chosen the Flee! Charge Reaction, after its Flee Move has been completed, the unit(s) that Declared a Charge towards it may attempt to Redirect their Charge.

To do so, each unit that has Declared a Charge towards the unit that fled may take a Command Test; a Redirect Test (see the Psychology chapter).
If the test is passed, the unit may immediately Declare a new Charge towards another unit (following all the usual restrictions for Declaring Charges).

Each unit may only attempt to Redirect a Charge once per Phase.
rulebook-charge_redirections.title: Charge Redirections

rulebook-charge_moves.def:
After all Charges and Charge Reactions have been declared and resolved, Charging Units will attempt to move into Combat.
Each unit that Declared a Charge in this Phase now rolls its Charge Range and, if successful, performs a Charge Move.

Roll and move units one by one.

/subsection{charge_range}/subsection{charge_move}/subsection{unaligned_charges}/subsection{combined_charges}/subsection{blocked_path}
rulebook-charge_moves.title: Charge Moves

rulebook-charge_range.def:
Roll D6+4 and add the unit’s Charge Speed (see Characteristic Profiles in the Definitions and Terminology chapter).

  • If the Charge Range is equal to or greater than the distance between the Charging Unit and its intended target (in inches), and if there is enough space to complete the Charge Move (including the Initial Align Move), then the Charge is successful and the Charging Unit performs a Charge Move.

  • Otherwise, the Charge is failed: the Charging Unit performs a Failed Charge Move.

Front or Flank?a) The centre of Charging Unit B’s Front Facing is located in enemy unit A’s Front Arc.\
b) The Charging Unit must contact the charged unit’s Front Facing.

Some players prefer to know their odds when Declaring Charges.\
Below are the probabilities for the most common cases.

Needed score to & 5" & 6" & 7" & 8" & 9" & 10"
D6+4 & 100% & 83% & 67% & 50% & 33% & 17%
Maximised*D6+4 & 100% & 97% & 89% & 75% & 56% & 31%

*Maximised rolls are explained in the Definitions and Terminology chapter.
rulebook-charge_range.title: Charge Range

rulebook-charge_move.def:
A Charge Move is divided into two sub-moves: first a Snaking Forward Move to get into contact with the target unit, then an Align Move.

Start with establishing in what Arc of the target unit, that the centre of the Charging Unit’s Front Facing is located in (see figure above).

The Facing that corresponds to this Arc is the Target Facing.

See Definitions and Terminology chapter for definitions of Arcs and Facings.

A Charge Move is performed using a single Snaking Forward Move (see Movement Phase chapter for details), with an unlimited distance.

During this move, the Charging Unit must move into contact with its intended target - The Charging Unit’s Front Facing against the Target Facing.

Charge Moves are allowed to end the move within 1" of Impassable Terrain or other units, but are not allowed to move into contact with any enemy unit, other than the target of the Charge.

Once the Charging Unit touches its Target Facing, it performs an Align Move.

This is done by picking up the Charging Unit and placing it back on the Battlefield aligned with the target unit, in a way that keeps the initial point of contact on the charged unit still in contact, while maximising the number of models in contact. See the Reference Handbook for details on how to prioritise the Initial Align Move in complex situations.

Apply the following rules when performing Align Moves.

The entire Charge Move must be made in such a way that the Charging Unit can satisfy the following conditions as best as possible, in decreasing order of priority:

  • The initial point of contact* on the target unit, before the Align Move, must remain in contact* after the Align Move.

Note that the Charging model that initially made contact is not required to remain in contact*.

  • If there is no single initial point of contact*, e.g. because the initial contact* is made along a line, the Charging Unit decides where the initial point of contact* is, among the possible points of initial contact*.

This choice must be made such that the conditions below are satisfied as best as possible.

  • The Charging Unit is fully aligned with its Front Facing flush against the Target Facing.

  • If this is not possible, apply the rules for Unaligned Charges (see below).

  • The number of models in the target unit that are in contact* with an enemy unit must be maximised. This includes Fighting Over Gaps.

  • The number of models in the Charging Unit that are in contact* must be maximised. This includes Fighting Over Gaps.

If it is unavoidable to break one or more of the above conditions, prioritise maintaining the higher priority conditions, even if it means breaking a greater number of conditions in total.

As long as all the above conditions are satisfied to the best extent possible, the Charging Unit is free to choose how it performs the Align Move.

ReferenceManualColorExample of a Charge Move. From left to right.1. Declare Charge: Unit A Declares a Charge towards unit B.
2. Initial Forward: Unit A moves straight forward.
3. Wheel: The unit is rotated forward around its front right corner.
4. Concluding Forward: Unit A moves forward again, until it contacts unit B.
5. Align: Unit A is picked up and put back down in contact and fully aligned with unit B.

Now me and Fleabag, when we’re working a mark, our most reliable method is the old one-two. It’s a classic for a reason. Go straight in and try to pinch the goods on your lonesome, you’re asking for a pointed intryductshin to a boot or five. But if the hound creeps up one way, and Klepa sidles over from behind, I can often have a leeesurely peroosal of pockets and purses before they know a thing. Teamwork makes the dream work – or as we Warborn say, broodwork makes the mood work!
rulebook-charge_move.title: Charge Move

rulebook-unaligned_charges.def:
If the Charging Unit cannot perform the Initial Align Move so that it is both fully aligned with the enemy, and the initial point of contact* remains in contact (Align Move conditions 1 and 2), the following rules are used instead:

The Charge Move and Align Move(s) must be made in such a way that the initial point of contact on the charged unit, before the Initial Align Move, remains in contact after the Initial Align Move, and such that, at the end of both Align Moves, the Charging Unit’s Front Facing does not cross over the projected line running parallel with the Target Facing.
Corresponding to the area marked in red in step 1 of Figure figure/example_Charge_move.

After making sure that the Charge will be possible without breaking the above condition, the Charging Unit must satisfy the conditions below as best as possible, in decreasing order of priority:

  • The initial point of contact on the charged unit, before the Initial Align Move, must remain in contact* after the Initial Align Move.
Note that the Charging model that initially made contact is not required to remain in contact.

  • Minimise the angle between the Front Facing of the Charging Unit and the Target Facing.

  • The number of models in the charged unit that are in contact* (taking into account those Fighting Over Gaps) must be maximised.

  • The number of models in the Charging Unit that are in contact* (taking into account those Fighting Over Gaps) must be maximised.

*Contact here is referring to contact between Unit Boundaries, including Fighting Over Gaps.

After performing the Initial Align Move with the Charging Unit, the charged unit performs a Special Align Move.
A unit that is Engaged can never perform a Special Align Move.

It is picked up and rotated around the point of contact, such that the angle between the Charging Unit’s Front Facing and the Target Facing is minimised, possibly and ideally fully aligning the units with each other.

Note: Any units not fully aligned must Combat Reform whenever possible. See Melee Phase chapter for details.
rulebook-unaligned_charges.title: Unaligned Charges

rulebook-combined_charges.def:
When more than one unit has Declared a Charge towards the same enemy unit, the Charging units are moved in a slightly different order.

  • Roll Charge Range for each unit Charging that same target before moving any of them.

  • Decide the order that the units will be moved, both Charge Moves and Failed Charge Moves. This must be chosen so that the number of units that successfully completes a Charge is as high as possible.

  • Move the units, one by one, following the normal Charge Move rules with the following exceptions:


  • Never apply the rules for Unaligned Charges or Blocked Path.

If it is not possible to place the Charging Unit fully aligned with the enemy, the Charge is not possible.

  • Each individual unit is not required to maximize the number of models in contact, conditions 4 and 5.
The conditions are instead applied at the end of all the Charge Moves.

This means that the total number of models from both sides are maximized after all successful Charges have been resolved.

  • In situations where not all the Charging Units can complete their Charge Move, e.g. due to other units blocking the path, such units will instead perform a Failed Charge Move.
rulebook-combined_charges.title: Combined Charges

rulebook-blocked_path.def:
To prevent abusive situations where a unit cannot Charge a nearby unit due to convoluted positioning of enemy units, the following rules are applied.

Blocked Path can only be applied against enemy units that fullfil all of the following criteria:

  • The enemy unit is directly in front of your unit.
This means that the first obstacle (other unit or Impassable Terrain) that a straight Forward Move of your unit would hit is an enemy unit.

  • Your unit would be unable to perform a Charge Move to get into contact with the Target Facing of the enemy unit.

  • The Charge is not made impossible due to friendly units Engaged with the Target Facing of the enemy unit. (i.e. Blocked Path is not applicable if the Charge is made impossible due to your own units being Engaged with the Target Facing)

In this situation, your unit may Declare a Charge towards the enemy unit, and if the enemy does not Flee, use the Facing that is adjacent to the Target Facing and closest to your Charging Unit (and perform a Charge Move as normal towards this new Target Facing).
rulebook-blocked_path.title: Blocked Path

rulebook-failed_charge_move.def:
A Failed Charge Move occurs when a unit cannot complete its Charge (e.g., due to an insufficient Charge Range, or due to obstacles making it impossible to complete the Charge Move).

The Failed Charge Distance is always 4".

If a unit suffers casualties during the Charge Move and therefore no longer can complete the Charge, the unit is also considered to have failed its Charge.

The unit’s movement is then backtracked to the position it had when declaring the Charge Move, then it performs a Failed Charge Move.

A Failed Charge Move is done by performing a Snaking Forward Move (see Manoeuvre Types in the Movement Phase chapter) with the following adjustments:

  • Initial Forward move is always 0".

(i.e. a Failed Charge Move starts with a Wheel.)

  • Wheel towards the intended target until one of the following occurs:

  • The unit is facing the direction where a forward move would bring the centre of the Charging Unit straight towards the centre of the Target Facing,

  • The Wheel is 90 degrees.

  • The Wheeled distance is equal to the Failed Charge Distance.

  • The unit is about to come into contact with another unit or Impassable Terrain.

Stop just before moving into contact.

  • Concluding Forward move until one of the following occurs:

  • The unit has moved a total distance (Wheel + Forward Move) equal to the Failed Charge Distance (4").

  • The unit is about to come into contact with another unit or Impassable Terrain. Stop just before moving into contact.

A unit that has performed a Failed Charge Move cannot perform any Move Manoeuvres in the same Player Turn, and it cannot shoot in the next Shooting Phase.

If the target was removed as a casualty, perform the Failed Charge Move towards the last position of the centre of the Target Facing.

Failed Charge Moves are allowed to end the move within 1" of Impassable Terrain or other units, but are not allowed to move into contact.
rulebook-failed_charge_move.title: Failed Charge Move

rulebook-engaged_in_combat.def: Once a unit completes a Charge Move, the Charging Unit and the target unit are Engaged in Combat, and remain Engaged in Combat as long as, at least their Unit Boundaries, are in contact with an enemy Unit Boundary.
rulebook-engaged_in_combat.title: Engaged in Combat

rulebook-movement_phase.def:
Positioning your forces well is the cornerstone of effective military strategy. The Movement Phase is a crucial opportunity to redeploy each of your units to the place where it can do the most good, setting up your attacks, bombardments, feints and cunning ploys to pay off in subsequent phases and turns. Troops in military formation must learn a range of orderly manoeuvres to accomplish such movements as efficiently as possible.

In the Movement Phase, you can move your units one by one in any order. Choose a unit and perform a Move Manoeuvre. Repeat this for all your eligible and willing units.

There are certain restrictions on which units can be moved during the Movement Phase.
The following units are not allowed to move:

  • Units that attempted to Charge in the current Player Turn.

  • Units that are Engaged in Combat.

  • Units that are Shaken.

  • Units that have arrived on the Battlefield using
Ambush during the current Player Turn.

/section{manoeuvres_types}/section{move_manoeuvres}
rulebook-movement_phase.title: Movement Phase

rulebook-manoeuvres_types.def:
Manoeuvre Types are different actions that can be made as part of other moves.
For example, a Snaking Forward Move is used during Charge, Advance and March Moves, while Pivots are made during Advance Moves and Post-Combat Pivots.

I know it might seem strange to think, but people who aren’t goblins sometimes like to move about in an organiferised fashion. Those sole-jers love nothing so much as marching up and down like lemmings with their perfect timing. What’s wrong with a good old crazed rush, I ask you, with everyone tripping over each other the way the gods intended? Some people just want to take the joy out of the mob.

/subsection{pivot}/subsection{snaking_forward_move}
rulebook-manoeuvres_types.title: Manoeuvres Types

rulebook-pivot.def:
When performing a Pivot, first mark the Centre of the unit. Then temporarily remove the unit from the Battlefield, and place it back facing any direction, while keeping its Centre in the same position as before.
Models may be repositioned within the unit, as long as the number of files does not change.

No single model can be moved further than twice its Mobility (see Characteristic Profiles in the Definitions and Terminology chapter) from its starting to its ending position.
Check by measuring the direct path of the centre of each model’s base.
rulebook-pivot.title: Pivot

rulebook-snaking_forward_move.def:
A Snaking Forward Move is broken down into three optional actions, which are carried out in this order:

1 - Initial Forward Move: the unit moves straight forward.
2 - Wheel: the unit is rotated forward around one of its front corners, up to 90 degrees.
3 - Concluding Forward Move: the unit moves straight forward.

Most Snaking Forward Moves have a limit to the distance the unit can move.
Add the distance used for each action to a total.
This total cannot exceed the maximum Snaking Forward Move distance.

For Forward Moves (steps 1 and 3), the moved distance is the distance the unit moves forward.
The distance used for the Wheel (step 2) is the distance the outer front corner is moving in the unit’s straight forward direction (see Figure figure/snakingForward).

Only consider the unit’s Front Facing during the entire Manoeuvre (e.g. for the Unit Spacing rule) until after the Manoeuvre is completed, where the whole Unit Boundary is again taken into account (i.e. the unit must abide by the Unit Spacing rule at its final position).

If the Snaking Forward Move is made as part of a Charge Move, the Manoeuvre also includes the Initial Align Move (i.e. only consider the Front Facing until after the Initial Align Move has been completed).

Mid-Move Actions

If, for any reasons, the unit’s or an individual model’s position is relevant in the middle of an ongoing Snaking Forward Move (such as when performing a Sweeping Attack or taking a Dangerous Terrain Test), the position of the unit is considered as follow:

  • At the start of the Snaking Forward Move, before moving the unit at all, the unit is collapsed into a line – its Front Facing. Everything behind this line moves straight forward until they meet the Front Facing. The unit then moves forward as this single line.

  • Note that the models still have a width (but no depth), equal to the width of their base; also note that this move can cause Dangerous Terrain Tests if used with a move type that triggers Dangerous Terrain Tests, such as Charge or March Moves.

  • When the unit reaches its final position at the end of the Snaking Forward Move, it expands to regain its depth again.

This is done by having the rear parts of the unit moving straight back from the Front Facing until they reach their original position within the unit formation.

Panic During Moves

If a unit has to take a Panic Test during any kind of move, do not take this test until the end of the move.

Snaking Forward MoveThe unit first performs an Initial Forward Move by moving straight forward.
The unit then Wheels by rotating forward around its right front corner.
Finally, the unit performs a Concluding Forward Move, where it moves straight forward again.

Simplified Snaking Forward Move
blank line

When executing a Snaking Forward Move, you can quickly check possible moves by using a measuring stick that has the same length as the width of the unit. Place this stick parallel with the unit’s Front Facing, then move the stick using the Snaking Forward Move rules. This stick represents the Front Facing of the unit.

  • If you are not happy with the end position, put this stick back along the Front Facing of the unit and try again.

  • Once you are happy with the position, leave the stick in its place and now move the unit to this position, aligning its Front Facing with the measuring stick.

ReferenceManualColor
A		 ReferenceManualColor
B \

ReferenceManualColorExample of Wheeling and PivotingA. Example of a Pivot. The unit is rotated around its Centre. During this rotation, the unit is removed from the table, and then placed back facing a new direction. When measuring a Pivot, it’s recommended that you start off by marking the Centre of the unit. You can do this without moving the unit, by placing four markers around it, such that they form a cross with its centre under the unit’s Centre. Then remove the unit and place it back, with its Centre again on the centre of the marked cross.

B. Example of a Wheel. The unit is rotated forward, around one of its front corners. The distance the unit is considered to have travelled is equal to the distance the unit’s outer front corner has moved in the straight forward direction, indicated by the red line in the figure. The example Wheel moved 4". When measuring a Wheel, it is recommended to place a measuring stick next to the unit and aligned towards the unit’s forward direction. Then wheel the unit to the wanted position, and then read off the distance from the measuring stick by checking how far the front corner moved, as indicated by the dotted line in the figure above.
rulebook-snaking_forward_move.title: Snaking Forward Move

rulebook-move_manoeuvres.def:
There are three different Move Manoeuvres.
When a unit moves in the Movement Phase, it must select which Move Manoeuvre it will perform:

  • Advance Move

  • March Move

  • Reform Move

Remember that since you are allowed to perform any measurements at any time, it is possible to test a Move Manoeuvre, realise it was not a great idea, and then immediately backtrack and perform a different Move Manoeuvre, unless random events or decisions by the opponent have happened that could influence the decision.
It is also customary to mark the starting position, so that backtracking can be done accurately.



Reform Moves allow units to tactically adjusts their arrangement on the field, granting them the strategic edge to adapt to new challenges during battle. This controlled shift is used to optimise positioning, formation and facing, white staying mostly in the same spot.

Advance Moves provide units with the freedom to manoeuvre on the battlefield, making it a versatile choice for repositioning when preparing to engage with the enemy.

March Moves are the fastest but least flexible movement option available to units. It allows them to move quickly in a forward direction.
Valid Final Position

For the final position of the unit to be considered valid, regardless of which Move Manoeuvre was performed, the following condition must be met.

If not, the Move Manoeuvre cannot be performed.

  • Each corner of the unit’s end position must be within twice its Mobility value (2×Mob inches) of at least one corner’s starting position.
Note that this does not mean that each corner must be within 2×Mob inches of its own starting position.

For simplicity, measure the corner that is furthest away from the starting position, and check by measuring its distance to the starting position of the closest corner.





ReferenceManualColorExample of how to measure Valid Final PositionThe unit Moves Forward and Wheels to face right.
When reaching the end position, make sure that the corner that travelled furthest is still within 2×Mob of at least one of the corners of the unit’s starting position (marked in red dashed lines in the figure).




/subsection{advance_move}/subsection{march_move}/subsection{reform_move}
rulebook-move_manoeuvres.title: Move Manoeuvres

rulebook-advance_move.def:
When performing an Advance Move, execute the following actions in the order given below:

1 - Pivot: the Advance Move is initiated with a Pivot. At the end of this Pivot, the unit must follow the Unit Spacing rule.
Note that since this is during a move, the unit normally just need to be outside 0.5" of other units.
2 - Snaking Forward Move (Mob): after the Pivot, the unit may do any number of Snaking Forward Moves, with a total distance up to its Mobility (in inches).
While performing these Snaking Forward Moves, the direction the unit is facing must stay within 90 degrees (in either direction) from the direction it was facing after the Pivot.
3 - Reorder: models may be repositioned within the unit, as long as the number of files does not change.
rulebook-advance_move.title: Advance Move

rulebook-march_move.def:
When performing a March Move, execute the following actions in the order given below:

1 - Snaking Forward Move (2×Mob): the unit may do any number of Snaking Forward Moves, with a total distance up to twice its Mobility (in inches).
While performing these Snaking Forward Moves, the direction the unit is facing must stay within 90 degrees (in either direction) from the direction it was facing before the March Move.
2 - Reorder: models may be repositioned within the unit, as long as the number of files does not change.
rulebook-march_move.title: March Move

rulebook-reform_move.def:
To do a Reform Move, pick the unit up from the battlefield and put it back with the following restrictions:

  • The Centre of the unit cannot travel further than half the unit’s Mobility (in inches).

  • The formation of the unit may change, but the number of Files cannot change by more than 2.
Remember that no unit can voluntarily have more ranks than files, unless it is wide enough to have a Proper Rank, see Models and Units in the Definitions and Terminology chapter).

  • Each model is considered to have moved from its starting position to its end position, around Obstructions where needed; no single model can move further than twice its Mobility.

When measuring each model’s move, it is considered to move independently of its unit, in any direction or combination of directions, including side- and back-stepping.
While moving, models can ignore other models from the same unit, but not from other units.
No single model can move further than twice its Mobility (in inches). Check this by measuring the path that the centre of each model moves on the Battlefield, from its starting to its ending position (including the path winding around obstacles).

Treat each model as an individual unit following the Unit Spacing rule.

At the end of this move, all models come back together again into a viable formation as described above.

ReferenceManualColorSimplified Reform Move

In practice, for the vast majority of Reform and Advance Moves, there is no need to consider the movements of individual models.

The upper image shows the technical way to perform a Reform Move: moving models one by one (grey dotted lines), and measuring distance the centre of each model moved (black dotted line).\
The lower image show a simplified method to perform a Reform Move: move the unit as a whole, potentially readjusting formation by adding or removing files. Measure the distance moved by the Centre of the unit, while making sure that no single model moves further than twice its Mobility (this can typically be checked by measuring the distance travelled by the models that have moved the furthest).\

ReferenceManualColorExample of Reform Move

Mid-Reform Move Actions

If, for any reasons, a model’s position is relevant during a mid-Reform Move (such as during a Sweeping Attack or Dangerous Terrain Tests), the unit must be placed in a viable formation and following the Unit Spacing rule (0.5") at the point where it becomes relevant, before continuing the move.
If it cannot be placed, the move cannot be performed.
When measuring the distance each model moves, measure from its starting position, to the position it is placed mid-move, and then finally to its ending position.
rulebook-reform_move.title: Reform Move

rulebook-magic_phase.def:
In the Magic Phase, your Wizards will summon the magic swirling across the battlefield and use it to cast spells that blast the enemy or bolster your own forces – while your opponent tries to stop you.
In the Magic Phase, your Wizards will summon the magic swirling across the battlefield and use it to cast spells that blast the enemy or bolster your own forces – while your opponent tries to stop you. Wizards are trained in one of the ten Paths of magic; their powers are limited by their own skill and by the availability of nearby magic, represented as Magic Dice. This store of power can be increased by channelling additional magic through the Veil – but be careful, for if you use too much magic to cast a spell, you run the risk of losing control!

The Magic Phase is divided into the following steps:

1 - Draw Flux Card
2 - Siphon the Veil
3 - Store Magic Dice
4 - Apply Excess Magic
5 - Casting and Dispelling Spells: the Active Player attempts to cast a spell with one of their models; the Reactive Player may attempt to Dispel it.
& Repeat step 5 for each spell you want to cast, or until out of Magic Dice.




/section{magic_dice_and_flux_cards}/section{siphon_the_veil}/section{storing_magic}/section{excess_magic}/section{spells}/section{miscast_table}
rulebook-magic_phase.title: Magic Phase

rulebook-magic_dice_and_flux_cards.def:
In the Magic Phase, players use Magic Dice for casting and dispelling spells. Each player receives a number of Magic Dice that can be used for the duration of this Magic Phase. Once a Magic Dice is used, it is discarded. At the end of the phase, any unused Magic Dice are discarded (except if stored, see Storing Magic below.).

Flux Cards


Each player has a deck consisting of the 8 Flux Cards selected from the list of 16 cards below. Which cards are used depends on the Army Size.\
For example, when playing at Field Armies Army Size, use Flux Cards V–XII. Flux Cards for printing can be found in the Arcane Compendium.\
During step 1 of the Magic Phase, randomly draw one of the Flux Cards from the Active Player’s deck. This card determines how many starting Magic Dice both players receive in this Magic Phase. Once a Flux Card has been drawn, it is discarded from the deck.

The remaining Flux Cards in both decks are open information to both players.


Warbands Warbands
and Field Armies		 Field Armies
and Grand Armies		 Grand Armies
I4 V4 IX5 XIII6
II4 VI5 X5 XIV7
III5 VII6 XI6 XV8
IV6 VIII6 XII7 XVI8
rulebook-magic_dice_and_flux_cards.title: Magic Dice and Flux Cards

rulebook-siphon_the_veil.def:
The Active Player gains additional Magic Dice from the following sources:


  • One free additional Magic Dice.

  • Magic Dice from models with Channel.

  • Magic Dice stored from the previous phase (see Storing Magic).

Note: each non-Shaken model with Channel(X) adds X Magic Dice. The most common source of Channel are Wizards:

  • Wizard Adepts have Channel(1).

  • Wizard Masters have Channel(2).

  • Wizard Conclaves have Channel(1), unless it is a Wizard Conclave (1).



-1


I hope you haven’t been listening to any criminal goblins. That would be almost as inadvisable as talking to an undergraduate!
Herr Sigmund Selig here, Professor Emeritus; you may call me The Sage. Forgive my tardiness, but I’d just seen a paper by that buffoon of a provost from Eichtal, claiming that the Flux responds to the seniority of the mage who calls upon it. Naturally I had to write a treatise in response – the Flux is simply the vulgar term for the flow of magic into and around our Realm, and all proper experiments demonstrate that though a wizard might draw more of this substance to themselves by “channelling”, they cannot increase the total magical resources in the vicinity, which is entirely random. Thank goodness I was in time to correct you on that!
rulebook-siphon_the_veil.title: Siphon the Veil

rulebook-storing_magic.def:
After Siphon the Veil and before Excess Magic, the Active Player may discard one Magic Dice.
If so, they gain one Magic Dice during the Siphon the Veil step of their next Magic Phase.

Warbands Warbands
and Field Armies		 Field Armies
and Grand Armies		 Grand Armies
I4 V4 IX5 XIII6
II4 VI5 X5 XIV7
III5 VII6 XI6 XV8
IV6 VIII6 XII7 XVI8
rulebook-storing_magic.title: Storing Magic

rulebook-excess_magic.def:
After both Siphon the Veil and Storing Magic, if a player has more than twice the number of Magic Dice in his pool than the number gained from the Flux Card, the player must discard each Magic Dice over this limit.\
For example, Flux Card XI grants 6 Magic Dice: it sets the Excess Magic limit to a maximum of 12 Magic Dice.
rulebook-excess_magic.title: Excess Magic

rulebook-spells.def:
Spells are divided into two broad categories:

  • Learned Spells: the most common type, these are cast using the full power of the magic flowing from beyond the Veil.

  • Bound Spells: bound into an object or creature, they are more stable than Learned spells, since their use requires only a minimum quantity of ambiant magic. These are cast by all manner of creatures, as well as some Wizards.

Most spells belong to a specific Path of Magic (see the Arcane Compendium), or are a Hereditary Spell unique to each Army Book.

/subsection{casting_and_dispelling_spells}/subsection{casting_multiple_instances_of_the_same_spell}/subsection{bound_spells}
rulebook-spells.title: Spells

rulebook-casting_and_dispelling_spells.def:
Each of the Active Player’s models with one or more spells can attempt to cast each spell up to once per Magic Phase. (Remember that Shaken models cannot cast spells.) The sequence for casting a spell is as follows:

Well no, I’m not a magician myself; I am a scholar, and one of the finest minds in Avras, I’ll have you know! And I have read all there is to know about magic, including the drivel that Heisermann calls his magnum opus.
Any true wizard will tell you that magic comes at a cost; too much of the stuff is lethal. It’s a mutagenic poison, after all. A withering, corrupting substance. And those with the proper training can feel the limits of what their body can tolerate instinctively – they cannot use more than is good for them any more than you could stop breathing.



Casting Roll – Active Player

1 - Caster and target: declare which model is casting what spell, and choose a target (or targets) for the spell (for details, see Spell Types in the Arcane Compendium).
2 - Spend Magic Dice to cast: declare how many Magic Dice are spent on the Casting Roll (at least 2 Magic Dice must be used, and at most 5 Magic Dice can be used).
3 - Roll Dice: roll the Magic Dice used for the Casting Roll, and add the results together. If the total is equal to or above the spell’s Casting Value, the casting is successful. Otherwise, the Casting Roll failed: go directly to step 7.

  • Fizzle: if one or more ‘1’ was rolled, and the Casting Roll was not successful, each dice that rolled a ‘1’ is added back to the Magic Dice pool.

  • Miscast: if three or more Magic Dice – or two Magic Dice if using only two dice – used for the Casting Roll gave an identical result, and the Casting Roll is successful, and the spell is not dispelled, a Miscast occurs. Consult the Miscast Table for further instructions.


Dispelling Roll - Reactive Player

4 - Spend Magic Dice to dispel: the Reactive Player may try to dispel the spell. If not, go directly to step 6. If the Reactive Player chooses to try to dispel, they declare how many Magic Dice are spent on the Dispelling Roll. Note: there are no limits to how many or how few Magic Dice the Reactive Player may use for this.
5 - Dispelling Roll: roll the Magic Dice used for the Dispelling Roll, and add the results together. If the total is equal to or above the Casting Roll, the dispel is successful: proceed to step 7. Otherwise, the Dispelling Roll failed: proceed to step 6.

  • Fizzle: if one or more ‘1’ was rolled, and the Dispelling Roll was not successful, each dice that rolled a ‘1’ is added back to the Magic Dice pool.


Resolving the spell effect

6 - Apply spell effects: if the Casting Roll was successful, and the spell was not dispelled, it is successfully cast. Apply the spell effects.

Spell effects are never affected by any effects affecting the Caster, including Magic Items, Model Rules, other spell effects, or similar abilities, unless specifically stated otherwise.

Removing the Caster of a spell as a casualty does not affect the spells duration.

7 - Next casting attempt: afterward, the Active Player may attempt to cast other spells, provided they have enough Magic Dice left.
rulebook-casting_and_dispelling_spells.title: Casting and Dispelling Spells

rulebook-casting_multiple_instances_of_t.def:
Each Caster may only try to cast each of its Learned Spells once per Magic Phase, and may try to cast a Bound Spell once for every instance of that spell it has. If multiple Casters know the same spell, all of them may try to cast their instance(s) of the spell.\
When attempting to cast a Learned Spell when a casting attempt (successful or not) has already been made for another instance of the same spell (either Bound or Learned), then the Casting Roll is reduced by -3, and by another -3 for each additional attempt in the same phase. For example, if two casting attempts have already been made for different instances of the same spell, any third attempt to cast it will suffer a -6 penalty to its Casting Roll.\
If the additional casting attempt is made for a Bound Spell version of the same spell, the Casting Roll is only reduced by -1, instead of by -3, for each previous casting attempt for a version of the same spell.\
Remember that Replicable Spells ignore this penalty to multiple casting attempts.
rulebook-casting_multiple_instances_of_t.title: Casting Multiple Instances of the Same Spell

rulebook-bound_spells.def:
Casting and dispelling Bound Spells follow the normal procedure for casting a Learned Spell, with the following exceptions:

  • Bound Spells have their own Casting Values, defined in the brackets following Bound Spell.

  • When trying to cast a Bound Spell, one Magic Dice is a D6, the rest are D3. For example, if casting a Bound Spell using 3 Magic Dice, roll 1D6 and 2D3.
  • A rolled D3 can never Fizzle.

  • Bound Spells can never Miscast.
