When casting a Bound Spell version of a spell for which a casting attempt was already made in the same Magic Phase, the Casting Roll is decreased only by -1 (instead of by -3).\
Note: when attempting to cast a Learned Spell version of a Bound Spell for which a casting attempt was already made in the same Magic Phase, the Casting Roll is still decreased by -3, as usual. This penalty is ignored if the spell is Replicable.

Bound Spells are designed to offer low-resource and low-risk casting opportunities to the players. They typically require fewer dice for casting and never cause Miscasts. However, they are also easier to dispel. As a result, Bound Spells are the perfect tool when the opponent is out of Magic Dice for dispelling.

When casting Bound Spells, it is important to clearly differentiate the D6s and the D3s. Announce to the opponent how you roll your dice, and either roll them separately, use differently coloured dice, or use dedicated D3-only dice.
rulebook-bound_spells.title: Bound Spells

rulebook-miscast_table.def:
A Casting Roll for a Learned Spell can result in a Miscast if the following conditions are all met:


  • Three-of-a-Kind or Two-of-a-Kind: the roll includes three or more Magic Dice that rolled the same result. If the Casting Attempt was made with only two Magic Dice, then it is sufficient for both of them to roll the same result.

  • Successful: the Casting Roll is successful, and the spell is not dispelled.

The effect of the Miscast depends on the total sum of the Casting Roll (including potential modifiers). Apply the effects that correspond to the total rolled.

Casting Roll Miscast effect
9 or less Drained
Your opponent gains 2 Magic Dice.
1019 Witchfire
The Caster’s unit suffers 2×X hits with Str 3, AP 2, and Magical Attacks, where X is the number of Magic Dice used for the Casting Roll.
2024 Amnesia
The Caster cannot cast this spell again. Duration: Permanent.
25+ Breach in the Veil
All units within 3" of the Caster suffer the effect of Witchfire.
After resolving this effect, the Caster is removed as a casualty.


Klepa tells you a story, everyone knows it where we’re from, absolootelly true tale, no extra charge. Once upon times, there’s a wizard. Very powerful, very scary. Eats poor honest goblins for snacks, probably. No other wizard could do anything about him. In every battle he munches up armies with big, dreadfullest spells.
One day he decides to visit special lovely Garden of law-biding goblins. He wants to burn up happy home with fireballs. Everyone in big panic, running around, bumping into things. But one goblin, faverit of cunning Karuka, she pays a visit to the mean old wizard the night before he comes. He’s much too strong to fight straight-on, so she sneaks into his tower and hides in the cupboard.
And when he tries to make himself some toast for dinner with a baby fireball, she nudges the spell, just a little, so it fizzies away. And when he heats his water for a bath, she sends the magic off, so he has to wash cold. When he makes the broom come to life to clean his chamber, she makes it stumble and fall down. Madder and madder, finally he tries biggest spell he knows. Clever goblin lets it go, and the magic shakes the whole tower into rubble, with the nasty wizard inside, squished. And the goblins lived happily ever after, the end.

Some players prefer to know their odds before casting spells. Below are the probabilities for the most common Casting Values in the game. Recommended target probability to optimise the number of dice used in a typical Magic Phase is around 80-90%.

& & & & & 72% & 95% & 98% & 100% & 58% & 91% & 98% & 99% & 42% & 84% & 97% & 99% & 28% & 74% & 94% & 99% & 17% & 63% & 90% & 98% & 8% & 50% & 84% & 97% & 3% & 38% & 76% & 94% & 0% & 26% & 66% & 90%

& & & & & 92% & 99% & 100% & 100% & 83% & 99% & 99% & 100% & 66% & 97% & 99% & 100% & 48% & 93% & 99% & 100% & 31% & 86% & 99% & 99% & 16% & 75% & 98% & 99% & 6% & 61% & 94% & 99% & 0% & 55% & 89% & 99%

& & & & & 94% & 100% & 100% & 100% & 83% & 98% & 100% & 100% & 66% & 93% & 99% & 100% & 50% & 81% & 97% & 99% & 33% & 67% & 91% & 99%

at (current page.south) ;
rulebook-miscast_table.title: Miscast Table

rulebook-shooting_phase.def:
There are many kinds of shooting used by the armies of the 9th Age, from bows, guns and thrown weapons to arcane devices and grand artillery machines. With the exception of magical spells, the Shooting Phase is your chance to unleash all of your ranged attacks at the foe, thinning their forces without the risks of close melee. But of course the enemy may not make it easy, taking cover behind any battlefield shelter they can find to foil your attempts at a clear shot.

The Shooting Phase consists of the following steps:
1 - Choose one of your units and perform a Shooting Attack with it.
2 - Select the target of the attack and which models in the unit will shoot. Each model must have Line of Sight to at least one model in the Target unit and be within its effective range.
3 - Resolve the Shooting Attack.
4 - Repeat steps 1 to 3 with a different unit that has not yet performed a Shooting Attack during this phase, if desired.

When all units that can and want to shoot have done so, the Shooting Phase ends.

/section{choose_a_unit_and_a_target}/section{who_can_shoot}/section{shots_and_aim}
rulebook-shooting_phase.title: Shooting Phase

rulebook-choose_a_unit_and_a_target.def:
During the Shooting Phase, units containing Shooting Weapons or relevant Model Rules can perform Shooting Attacks.

Select a friendly unit as the Shooting unit and an enemy unit as the Target unit (for further details, see Allocating Attacks in the Attacks chapter).

  • Shooting unit: to be eligible to shoot, a unit must not:

  • Be Shaken,

  • Be Engaged in Combat,

  • Have performed a Failed Charge Move this Player Turn,

  • Have made a March Move this Player Turn (unless it has March and Shoot), or

  • Already used its Shooting Attack this Player Turn.

  • Target unit: to be eligible to be shot at, a unit must:

  • Be within the Shooting unit’s Line of Sight, and

  • Not be Engaged in Combat.

Target Facing
When checking Line of Sight from a Shooting model to the target, also simultaneously check which Facing is the Target Facing.
This is done by establishing in which Arc of the Target unit the centre of the Front Facing of the Shooting unit’s is located in: the corresponding Facing is referred to as Target Facing (i.e. it is determined in the same way as for Charging).
rulebook-choose_a_unit_and_a_target.title: Choose a unit and a target

rulebook-who_can_shoot.def:
Normally, only models in the first and second rank can shoot.

If different models in the unit have different types of Shooting Attacks, declare which one is used for each model. Each model can use their own Shooting Attacks.

Determine which models in the Shooting unit can shoot:

  • The model must be able to draw Line of Sight to at least one model in the Target unit.

  • The model must have the target Health Pool within the Range of its Shooting Attack: measure this from each model in the unit to the closest point of the Target unit’s Boundary.

Models that are outside their weapon’s Range cannot shoot.

  • All models in the Shooting unit must shoot at the same Target unit, but may, when possible, allocate their attacks towards different Health Pools within the targeted unit (see Allocating Attacks for rules on when Attachable Models joined to units may be chosen as the target).

  • Any model part in the unit can choose not to shoot.
rulebook-who_can_shoot.title: Who can shoot?

rulebook-shots_and_aim.def:
Once the models that will shoot are established, they each make as many shots as indicated in their weapon’s profile. Roll to hit by rolling a D6 for each shot and compare its result to the weapon’s Aim (written in brackets after the weapon’s name). For example, a dwarf warrior has Throwing Weapons(5+) with Shots 2. When this model shoots, roll two D6: each roll of 5+ is a successful hit.

For each hit, follow the Attack Sequence to determine the damage (see the Attacks chapter).

Everyone loves a good stab. But sometimes stabbing people can be more hassle than it’s worth. You have to get up close, so there’s the unlovely risk of being stabbed right back.
That’s why lots of people prefer shooting – what we goblins call stabbing from a distance. Beautiful to see, really: all the ways people have invented for battling far off, nice and impersonal. Arrows are an easy one, but nowadays there’s guns too, all kinds. And big machines with springs for lobbing your classic rock, or spurting out fire, or sending off spells…
Speaking of spurting fire, some things don’t even need a machine. Dragons is a scary one. Thought they were miffy-logical til one showed up in Avras, bold as brass. Weird creatures, dragons. Love to collect stuff, but won’t haggle with merchants. Won’t let anyone near them except one special friend they call a rider. You almost never see two dragons together, but some say they have big secret meetings where no one can see. Don’t bear thinking about – defnitly wouldn’t want to try stabbing one of them!

/subsection{tohit_modifiers}/subsection{cover}
rulebook-shots_and_aim.title: Shots and Aim

rulebook-tohit_modifiers.def:
The to-hit roll of a Shooting Attack can be modified, affecting the chance of scoring a successful hit. If the modifier brings the needed score to 7+ or beyond, the attack cannot hit, and a roll of ‘1’ is always considered a miss.
Apply the following modifiers to the to-hit roll:

  • Long Range (-1): if the target is more than half the weapon’s maximum Range away from the Shooting model, apply a -1 to-hit modifier.

  • Accurate: if the Shooting model part or its weapon has Accurate, ignore the modifier for Long Range.

  • Moving and Shooting (-1): if the Shooting model’s unit has performed a Move Manoeuvre (Advance, March or Reform*) in this Player Turn, apply a -1 to-hit modifier.

  • Quick to Fire: if the Shooting model part or its weapon has Quick to Fire, it does not suffer the normal -1 to-hit penalty for Moving and Shooting.

  • *Only model parts with March and Shoot (or using a weapon with that rule) can shoot after having Marched in the same Player Turn. If they do, the -1 to-hit modifier for Moving and Shooting applies.

  • Unwieldy (-X): if the Shooting model part or its weapon has Unwieldy and has performed a Move Manoeuvre during the same Player Turn, apply an additional -X to-hit modifier.

  • Cover: the target could benefit from either Soft Cover or Hard Cover:

  • Soft Cover (-1): if the target benefits from Soft Cover, apply a -1 to-hit modifier.

  • Hard Cover (-2): if the target benefits from Hard Cover, apply a -2 to-hit modifier.

  • Hard Target (X): if the Target unit has Hard Target, apply a -X to-hit modifier.

*See Model Rules for the full rules.
rulebook-tohit_modifiers.title: To-Hit Modifiers

rulebook-cover.def:
For each model that is shooting, check if the target benefits from Cover by drawing three straight lines from the Shooting model to the target.

These lines all start from the same point on the Shooting model’s base, as was used checking Line of Sight to the target.

  • One line is drawn to the right corner of the Target Facing.

  • One line is drawn to the left corner of the Target Facing.

  • One line is drawn to the centre of the Target Facing.

If two or more of these lines pass through Obstructions that contribute to Cover (both Soft or Hard), the target benefits from Soft Cover.
If at least two of these lines pass through Obstructions that contribute to Hard Cover, apply instead the rules for Hard Cover.

Example of Cover in the Terrain Feature.The centre of the blue unit’s Front Facing is located in the red unit’s Flank Arc: the Flank Facing is the Target Facing.

Two of three of the drawn lines pass through a Forest: the red unit benefits from Soft Cover.

Obstructions that Contribute to Cover

There are two types of Cover: Soft and Hard. The most common reason for applying Cover is the target being obscured by Terrain or other models, or the target being inside a Terrain Feature.

The following Obstructions contribute to Cover:

Soft Cover\

  • Terrain that is Covering Terrain* and that contributes to Soft Cover.

  • Models that have equal or larger Height than either the shooter or the target.

Hard Cover\

  • Terrain that is Opaque Terrain

  • Terrain that is Covering Terrain* and that contributes to Hard Cover.

  • Models that have equal or larger Height than both the shooter and the target.

*See the Terrain chapter for details.
Note that models that have a smaller Height than both the shooter and the target do not contribute to Cover.
rulebook-cover.title: Cover

rulebook-rally_phase.def:
The Battle of Merton’s Pass, AS 77, was fought between the dwarves of Nevaz Derom and the last survivors of the warherd originally led by Bragh, the Black Bull, who had been slain by Sunna.
The dwarven exploratory force was scattered by a sudden rush of hidden beasts, defending their valley refuge. But having fled in all directions, the dwarves rediscovered their courage – one imagines a certain amount of mumbled embarrassment – and the celebrating beasts soon found themselves trapped between armed companies on every side.
They say you can still hear the mournful lowing in Mertons Pass on cold nights. It’s a classic study in military history, though I’d advise you to skip Cagilio’s overlong treatise on dwarven tactics.

/section{rally_test}
rulebook-rally_phase.title: Rally Phase

rulebook-rally_test.def:
During the Rally Phase, the Active Player’s Shaken units must take a Command Test, called a Rally Test. Roll tests one by one in any order.
Units Engaged in Combat cannot take Rally Tests.

  • If the Rally Test is passed, the unit stops being Shaken and may immediately make a Pivot (see the Movement Phase chapter).

  • If the Rally Test is failed, the unit Pivots to face directly away from the centre of the closest non-Shaken enemy unit, and then performs a Flee Move (see the Psychology chapter).

Remember that any Decimated unit that performs a Flee Move is removed as casualty.
rulebook-rally_test.title: Rally Test

rulebook-melee_phase.def:
Some say that battles are won or lost by preparation or sound strategies, but ultimately every fight will come down to the clash of weapons in close quarters. The Melee Phase is the time for your forces to put their mettle to the test, once they have met the enemy in Combat, and discover whether their strength – and a touch of divine fortune – can bring them the victory. And perhaps more important, whether the defeated side can continue to fight on. This is also when your leaders and champions will meet in single Combat with their counterparts, fighting great duels that will live in legend.

During the Melee Phase, all Engaged units will attack each other: each group of interlocked units in contact with each other is called a Combat.

Each Combat goes through a Round of Combat, one Combat after another.

Giants are a fascinating species, pseudo-symbiotic with other peoples, whose instinct for friendship has led them to become weapons of war throughout history. Some call this tragic, some call it noble.

Today, with sixteen factions of growing strength locked in a delicate balance of power, certain bold, original, brilliant observers have hypothesised that perhaps it could be the trusting, suggestible giants that might tip the fragile equilibrium in favour of one group or another. You can find out more about this provocative, insightful idea in my latest three-volume masterwork, Giant By Name: How the World Underestimates Jotun Potential, available in all fine bookshops that stock self-published authors.

The Melee Phase is carried out using the following sequence:

I & Enemy Wiped. If a unit’s opponents have been removed outside the Melee Phase, the unit may perform a Post-Combat Pivot or an Overrun (if it was Charging).
II & Round of Combat. Each Combat is resolved in an order chosen by the Active Player.

For each Combat, follow this sequence:

  • Preparations for Combat

  • Remove Shaken units

  • Freeze Unit Boundaries

  • Combat Set-Up

  • Check Combat Formations

  • Static Combat Score

  • Choose Equipment and Abilities



  • Perform Melee Attacks


  • Determine Agility Order

  •

  • Resolve Attacks

  • Determine the Winner

  • Casualty-based Combat Score

  • Final Combat Score

  • Take Break Tests

  • Breaking and Pursuing

  • Determine who Flees and who Pursues

  • Unfreeze Unit Boundaries

  • Move Fleeing Units

  • Move Pursuing Units

  • Post Combat

  • Perform Post-Combat Pivots

  • Perform Combat Reforms

III & Repeat steps II for each Combat: choose a Combat and complete all actions in the Round of Combat Sequence for each unit in that Combat, before moving on to resolve the next Combat.
IV & Once all Combats have been resolved, the Melee Phase ends.

Enemy Wiped

Sometimes a unit that was previously Engaged in Combat had all its opponents removed before the start of the next Melee Phase.

Such units follow the rules for No More Foes.

If the unit has not moved since the enemy units were removed (e.g. with a Magical Move), it may perform a Post-Combat Pivot, or an the unit was considered Charging immediately before removing the enemy unit.

Combat

Each Combat is fought between a group of units that are in contact with each other. Most often, it involves only two opposing units Facing off, but it can also include multiple units against a single enemy unit, or a series of units from both sides all linked together.

The Active Player chooses one such Combat to fight in a Round of Combat (which means all actions connected to a Round of Combat must be resolved with all Engaged units).

Then the Active Player chooses a new Combat that has not been fought in this Melee Phase, to fight a Round of Combat.
Continue choosing and resolving Combats until all of them has been fought.

First Round of Combat
During the First Round of Combat, specific rules come into play.

A unit’s First Round of Combat occurs in two situations:


  • The First Round of Combat it fights after successfully Charging an enemy unit.

  • The First Round of Combat after it has been successfully charged by an enemy unit, whereas it was not already Engaged in Combat.


Combined Combats
Any Combat that involves more than two units is called a Combined Combat.

/section{preparations_for_combat}/section{combat_setup}/section{perform_melee_attacks}/section{determine_the_winner}/section{take_break_tests}/section{post_combat}
rulebook-melee_phase.title: Melee Phase

rulebook-remove_shaken_units.def:
Remove all models in Engaged units that are Shaken as casualties.

Remember that units Engaged in Combat do not take Panic Tests.

Therefore, the most common way for a Shaken unit to find itself in Combat, is if it gets charged when it was already Shaken.
rulebook-remove_shaken_units.title: Remove Shaken units

rulebook-freeze_unit_boundaries.def:
When resolving a Round of Combat, the Unit Boundaries of the Engaged units are not updated, but retain their sizes and positions.

Furthermore, the placement of models in those units is also not changed (e.g. to ensure viable formation when casualties are suffered).

When calculating the number of ranks, files, or Proper Ranks a unit has (this is primality relevant for Steady and Solid, empty gaps in the unit formation (e.g. due to a dead Attachable Model) are considered to be filled in by models from back ranks, in the same way you would normally fill empty gaps (see the Definitions and Terminology chapter for details).

Note that models are not physically moved at this stage.

Unit Boundaries remain Frozen until just before Broken units perform their Flee Moves or when the unit whose boundary it is, is removed as a casualty.

Note that the number of Proper Ranks can still be reduced for Steady or Solid purposes if models get removed during Combat.

Unit Boundaries and models’ positions are Frozen in place, in order to prevent the need to do any finicky movement and repositions in messy situations, at a time where players should be focusing on rolling their attacks.
rulebook-freeze_unit_boundaries.title: Freeze Unit Boundaries

rulebook-check_combat_formations.def:
Steady

A unit is Steady if it has more Proper Ranks than each individual enemy unit Engaged in contact with it.

If, at the end of a Round of Combat, the unit is Steady and was on the losing side, Discipline modifiers from the Combat Score difference are set to a minimum of -2 (i.e. cannot be a smaller number than -2).

Solid


A unit is Solid if its number of Proper Ranks is at least:


  • 4 – for units of Height 0-1.

  • 3 – for units of Height 2.

  • 2 – for units of Height 3-5.

If a Height 1 unit is Solid at the start of a Round of Combat, then all Height 1 models in the unit gain Press of Ranks (+1 to wound, max. 3+) until the end of the Round of Combat.

Steadfast

If, at the end of a Round of Combat, the unit is both Steady and Solid, it is said to be Steadfast: modifiers to the unit’s Discipline from the Combat Score difference are ignored when rolling Break Tests.

Always best to get the jump on the fuzz, not other way round. Need to be one step ahead in this game. Cannot just wait for them to get you – gotta seize the nishitive, or you’ll land yourself in the dungeons, and that in’t no fun at all. That’s what Klepa’s old witch-gaffa taught him, and that’s what Klepa would tell you if he weren’t upstanding honest pervayer of not-stolen goods.
Surrounded

A unit is considered Surrounded when it has enemies Engaged with either its Flank and/or Rear Facing.

A Surrounded unit counts as having X fewer Proper Ranks, where X is the combined number of Proper Ranks of all the enemy units Engaged on its Flank and/or Rear.

If multiple units in the same Combat are Surrounded, first apply Surrounded from units that are themselves not Surrounded. Then apply Surrounded from units that are Surrounded.

The Active Player chooses the order in which to perform each of these steps.

The primary effects of this are on the amount of Combat Score the unit will get for Proper Ranks (ie. Rank Bonus), and whether the unit and its enemies are Steady and/or Solid.

Note that a unit that has 0 Proper Ranks would be unaffected by this reduction.
rulebook-check_combat_formations.title: Check Combat Formations

rulebook-calculate_static_combat_score.def:
The goal of a Round of Combat is to annihilate or rout the enemy, the latter is done through winning the Round of Combat, by having your units accumulate a higher total Combat Score than the opponent’s units.

The Combat Score is calculated at two different steps:


  • First in step 2 of the Round of Combat Sequence (Combat Set-Up), where Static Combat Score bonuses are added up and marked down.

  • After all attacks have been made, at step 4 of the Round of Combat Sequence (Determine the Winner), Casualty-based Combat Score bonuses are added to calculate the final Combat Score.

The Static Combat Score bonuses are:


  • Charge: +1

Each side with one or more Charging units adds +1 to their Combat Score.

  • Fighting on the Flanks or the Rear: +2 / each Flank or Rear

If a side has units fighting the enemy in their Flank or Rear, it adds +2 to its Combat Score for each different Flank or Rear Facing of each enemy unit it has units Engaged on.

  • Rank Bonus: +1 / Proper Rank (up to +4)

Each side adds to its Combat Score the number of Proper Ranks of its unit that has the most Proper Ranks, up to a maximum of +4. Note that the Rank Bonus of a unit can be reduced if it is Surrounded.

See Models and Units in the Definitions and Terminology chapter for the definition of Proper Rank.

  • Standard Bearer: +1 / Standard Bearer

Each side adds +1 to its Combat Score for each units with a Standard Bearer Engaged in the Combat.

  • Other Modifiers

Additional modifiers can be added to each side’s Combat Score (such as +1 if the Battle Standard Bearer is Engaged in the Combat).

Combats can be messy and time-consuming to resolve. To simplify the process, we recommend placing special dice or markers next to the units to track the Static Combat Score.
rulebook-calculate_static_combat_score.title: Calculate Static Combat Score

rulebook-choose_equipment_and_abilities.def:
Many models have choices that are determined in this step of the Round of Combat Sequence.

Common ones: Make Way for Characters, Activate items and abilities and choose weapon.

If both players have choices to do in this step, the Active Player first makes and executes all their choices, then the Reactive Player makes and executes all their own choices.
Choose Melee Weapon

Model parts armed with multiple weapons must choose which weapon to use in their First Round of Combat, with the following priority order*:


  • An Enchanted Weapon

  • Any weapon that is neither a Hand Weapon, nor an Innate Weapon

  • A Hand Weapon

  • An Innate Weapon


*A model part with Weapon Master may choose what Melee Weapon to use in each Round of Combat, and only needs to conform to the Priority #1 hereabove.
rulebook-choose_equipment_and_abilities.title: Choose Equipment and Abilities

rulebook-determine_agility_order.def:
The order in which Melee Attacks are performed is determined before any attacks take place.

This order is known as the Agility Order and is based on the Agility of the attacking model parts.

The highest Agility attacks are resolved first, followed by lower Agility attacks.

Once the Agility Order is determined, it remains so for the entire Round of Combat.

Charging Momentum

Charging models gain +1 Agility.
rulebook-determine_agility_order.title: Determine Agility Order

rulebook-allocating_attacks.def:
When allocating Melee Attacks, each attack must choose a target. All attacks of the given Agility Step must be allocated before determining the number of hits.

Viable targets are:

  • Rank-and-File models in any unit whose Unit
Boundary (see Definitions and Terminology chapter) the attacker is in contact with.

  • Any Attachable Model that the attacker is in contact with.

If a model is making Supporting Attacks, it can allocate its attacks as if it was located in the Front Rank of the unit, in the same file.

/subsubsection{which_models_can_attack}

In the Attack Sequence, the first step is to determine the target: select a unit to attack, and which models in the unit to target. This works slightly different for Ranged Attacks than for Melee Attacks.

For Melee Attacks, if several attacks (such as from model parts in the same unit) attack simultaneously, each attack may be allocated towards a different target:

  • The attacker can always allocate its attacks to any Rank-and-File models in an enemy unit in contact.

  • Melee Attacks can be allocated to Attachable Models joined to an enemy unit if they are in contact with the attacker’s model (or, in the case of Supporting Attacks, in contact with a model directly in front of the attacker in the same unit).
See the Melee Phase chapter for details.

  • If the unit in contact with the attacker contains no Rank-and-File models then any model in that unit may be chosen as the target.

For Ranged Attacks, all simultaneous attacks from the same unit must select the same unit as their target, but may be allocated towards different Health Pools within the unit, if possible:


  • Attacks can always be allocated to Rank-and-File models in the target unit.
If there are no Rank-and-File models in the unit, then any model in the unit may be chosen as the target.

  • Attacks can be allocated to Attachable Models joined to the target unit if they are either or both:

  • Of a different Height than the Rank-and-File models in the unit.

  • In a unit with fewer than 5 Rank-and-File models (or fewer than 3 if they are of Height 3--5).

In cases where a single attack or effect is multiplied into several hits, repeat the attack allocation step once it has been established how many hits are scored. At least one hit must still be allocated towards the original target.

So if you cast a spell that causes D6 hits, targeting an enemy unit, and roll a ‘4’ to determine the number of hits, these hits can now be allocated to the different Health Pools in the unit, either the Rank-and-File models, or any Attachable Models meeting the criteria listed above.
rulebook-allocating_attacks.title: Allocating Attacks

rulebook-which_models_can_attack.def:
During the Melee Phase, models that are in contact with an enemy Unit Boundary when their designated Agility Step is reached must attack.

Except if they have been removed as a casualty.

Restricted Attacks

The rules for Restricted Attacks are used for Standard Melee Attacks in two circumstances:

  • Supporting Attacks: models in the second rank can use Standard Melee Attacks against enemies across models in the first rank, directly in front of them
(i.e. only against models Engaged with the Front Facing of their unit).

  • Flank and Rear: Restricted Attacks apply when a model allocates Standard Melee Attacks towards an enemy that is Engaged with its Flank or Rear Facing.

When a model intends to allocate any of its Standard Melee Attacks as Restricted Attacks, the total Standard Melee Attacks its combined model parts can make is never greater than its Height.

If the model has multiple model parts (see Models and Units in the Definitions and Terminology chapter), its owner may decide which attacks from what model parts are used, as long as the total number of attacks for the combined model does not exceed its Height.

For example, a Height 2 model consisting of a Knight (Att 2) on a Horse (Att 1) is making Supporting Attacks. This model can only perform 2 Standard Melee Attacks, and choose to first perform 1 attack with the Knight, and then at a lower Agility Step, 1 attack with the Horse.
Fighting Over Gaps

Models are considered to be in contact with each other across gaps.
This can happen if there are gaps in a unit formation, or if units are not perfectly aligned with each other.

To check if they are in contact, extend their bases in the direction of the Facing the unit is Engaged in.

If this contacts an enemy model on the Facing it is Engaged with, both models are considered to be in contact with each other.

The base cannot be extended past Impassable Terrain or a Unit Boundary belonging to a different unit.

See images below for examples.

\ Fighting over Gaps. – Left panel: Gaps in the unit formation. Models from the blue and red units are considered to be in contact over the gap indicated by the arrows a, b, and c.\
– Right panel: Imperfectly aligned units. The units are not perfectly aligned, but blue and red units are still considered to be in contact over the gap indicated by the arrows d and e.
rulebook-which_models_can_attack.title: Which Models can Attack

rulebook-resolve_attacks.def:
Resolve Melee Attacks from models in the Combat, in descending Agility Order.

For each attack, follow the Attack Sequence as defined in the Attacks chapter.

This includes models from both sides involved in the Combat.

/subsubsection{standard_melee_attacks}
rulebook-resolve_attacks.title: Resolve Attacks

rulebook-casualtybased_combat_score.def:
Once all Agility Steps have been resolved, i.e. all models have had a chance to attack, the Casualty-based Combat Score is calculated.

The Casualty-based Combat Score bonuses are:

  • Health Point losses caused on enemy units: +1 / Health Point

Add up the number of Health Points lost by your opponent’s units during the Round of Combat.

  • Wiped enemy unit: +1 / unit

Add +1 for each enemy unit where all the unit’s models were removed as casualties (in addition to the Health Points losses incurred by those units before being wiped out).

This includes Shaken units that were removed at the start of the Round of Combat; however, Shaken units only contribute with +1 for being wiped, no Health Point losses are taken into account.
rulebook-casualtybased_combat_score.title: Casualty-based Combat Score

rulebook-calculate_final_combat_score.def:
Determine which side won this Round of Combat.

This is done by adding the Casualty-based Combat Score bonuses to the previously calculated Static Combat Score bonuses

The side with the higher Combat Score wins, while the side with the lower Combat Score loses.

In case of a tie, both sides are considered winners.

A unit that is no longer in contact with any enemy units always counts as having won the Round of Combat.
rulebook-calculate_final_combat_score.title: Calculate Final Combat Score

rulebook-take_break_tests.def:
After a Round of Combat, each unit on the side that lost the Combat must take a Break Test, in an order chosen by the player who lost the Combat.

A Break Test is a Courage Test with a negative modifier equal to the difference in Combat Scores.

For example, if the Combat Score was 6 to 3, the units on the losing side take their Break Tests with a -3 modifier.

Note that rules such as Steady, Solid, Bodyguard and Stubborn can have an impact on what the Discipline modifier ends up as.

  • If the Break Test is passed, the unit remains Engaged in the Combat.

  • If the Break Test is failed, the unit is Broken, and will now attempt to Flee from the Combat.

-1

/subsection{determine_who_flees_and_who_brpursues}/subsection{unfreeze_unit_boundaries}/subsection{move_broken_units}/subsection{move_pursuing_units}/subsection{pursue_moves}
rulebook-take_break_tests.title: Take Break Tests

rulebook-determine_who_flees_and_who_brp.def:
If any unit failed its Break Test or was wiped out during the Combat, follow the steps below in order:

1 - Determine Flee Direction: each Broken unit (i.e. any unit that failed its Break Test) will Flee away from an enemy unit it is in contact with.

If there are more than one unit to Flee away from, the owner of those enemy units chooses which is used to establish the Flee direction.
2 - Roll Flee Distance: typically, this is a roll of 2D6.

Place the resulting dice next to the unit, but do not move the unit yet.
3 - Determine which units will Pursue: each unit in contact with one or more Broken enemy units, and no non-Broken enemy units, may choose to Pursue. Declare which unit is Pursuing which Broken unit.

  • A unit that was Charging in the previous Round of Combat and is now no longer in contact with any enemy unit (usually, because all of them have been wiped out) may choose to perform a special type of Pursuit called an Overrun.
An Overrun is always straight forward.

4 - Roll Pursue Distance: typically, this is a roll of 2D6.
Place the resulting dice next to the unit, but do not move the unit yet.
5 - Remove caught Broken units: compare the Flee Distance of each Broken unit with the Pursue Distances of any unit that Declared a Pursuit towards it.
If the Flee Distance is greater than all Pursue Distances, the Broken unit managed to get away. Otherwise, the unit was caught and is removed as a casualty.
rulebook-determine_who_flees_and_who_brp.title:
Determine who Flees and who
Pursues

rulebook-unfreeze_unit_boundaries.def:
The Unit Boundaries of any remaining units are unfrozen, and the models within the unit are rearranged to reform a valid formation.
See the Reference Handbook;
Maintaining a Viable Formation for details.

Afterwards, nudge units that are neither Breaking nor Pursuing back in contact with each other where contact was lost.
See the Reference Handbook; Nudge units to maintain contact for details.

Nudge units to maintain contact

After unfreezing Unit Boundaries and rearranging models within the unit to maintain valid formations, any unit that was Engaged in Combat just before this, but lost contact due to updated Unit Boundaries, is nudged back into contact.

This does not apply to units that are about to Flee, nor units that are about to Pursue.

Move units one at a time, in the order described below, until all units have either attempted to maintain contact and failed, or are back in contact with the enemy.

  • Move the Active Player’s units first.

  • Move all units on each side, in the order that allows the most units to remain in Combat.

  • If different ways of proceeding bring about the same amount of units remaining in Combat, each owner decides in which order their own units will be nudged.

Nudge each unit to maintain contact with the unit(s) it was in contact with before updating Unit Boundaries, following the rules below:

  • If the unit is in contact with an enemy, it is not nudged.

  • The unit cannot be nudged through units or Impassable Terrain.

  • The unit cannot be nudged into contact with any new enemy unit, but can end this move within 1" of other units and Impassable Terrain.

  • The unit must be moved by the minimum distance required to maintain contact.

  • The unit must be moved in a straight line: either directly forwards, directly backwards, sideways, or in a combination of two of these directions.

  • The unit cannot change which of its Facings are in contact with enemies.

If these rules do not allow the unit to maintain contact, do not move the unit at all.
Units that lose contact follow the rules for No More Foes.

If, as a result of updating Unit Boundaries, two or more separate groups of opposing units have been created, subgroup will be treated as a separate Combat from now on.

No More Foes

When a unit is unable to be nudged back into contact with enemies it previously was in contact with (including due to those enemy units no longer being on the Battlefield, e.g. because they have been removed as casualties, during or outside the Round of Combat, such that it finds itself no longer Engaged in Combat.

It may perform a Post-Combat Pivot, or if it was Charging, an Overrun.
rulebook-unfreeze_unit_boundaries.title: Unfreeze Unit Boundaries

rulebook-move_broken_units.def:
Each Broken unit that was not caught is now Shaken and will Flee from the Combat.

Move the units one by one in the order chosen by their owner.

First, Pivot the unit so that its Rear Facing is parallel with its Facing that was Engaged with the enemy unit it is Fleeing away from, by Pivoting either exactly 0, 90, or 180 degrees.

Then, the Broken unit performs a Flee Move straight forward by the previously rolled Flee Distance (see the Psychology chapter for Flee Move rules).
rulebook-move_broken_units.title: Move Broken Units

rulebook-move_pursuing_units.def:
Move each unit that declared a Pursuit one by one in the order chosen by their owner. First, Pivot the unit so that it is Facing the same direction as the Broken unit it is Pursuing.

Then, move the unit straight forward by a distance equal to the previously rolled Pursue Distance.

A unit that is performing an Overrun always moves straight forward without Pivoting.

If there are Pursuing units on both sides, the Active Player moves all their units first, then the Reactive Player moves their units.

If the Pursue Move would bring the Pursuing unit in contact with an obstacle, such as an enemy unit, the Table Edge or an Obstruction, specific rules apply.
(For details, see Pursue Moves in the Reference Handbook).

* During a Pursue Move, the following objects are considered to be Obstructions:


  • Impassable Terrain Feature

  • Friendly units that were not part of the same Combat

  • Enemy units that Fled from the Combat involving the Pursuing unit
rulebook-move_pursuing_units.title: Move Pursuing Units

rulebook-pursue_moves.def:
Before moving any unit, check:

  • Which Pursuing unit would be led to a Charge due to its Pursue Move, ignoring other Pursuing units.

  • Which Arc the centre of the Pursuing unit’s Front Facing is located in, For each enemy unit that might be Charged as part of the Pursue Move: if the Pursue Move will lead to a Charge, it will be in the Facing determined at this point.

The Charging units will be moved first.

The order must be chosen, so that the number of units that successfully completes a Charge is as high as possible.
The remaining Pursuing units will be moved afterwards, in an order chosen by their owner.

1. Pivot

The Pursuing unit Pivots so that it is Facing the same direction as the pursued unit or, if that unit was removed as a casualty, the direction the pursued unit would have had, if not removed as a casualty.
Ignore the Unit Spacing rule during this Pivot.

After the Pivot, one of the four situations will arise. If more than one is applicable, only apply the uppermost one:

  • Enemy unit: if, after the Pivot, the Front Facing of the Pursuing unit would be in contact with the Unit Boundary of an enemy unit that did not Flee from the same Combat, it Declares a Charge towards that unit, which cannot perform any Charge Reactions.
(If there is more than one possible target, the Pivoting unit chooses which unit to Charge.)

To perform the Charge Move, remove the Pursuing unit from the Battlefield, then place it back following the rules below:

  • It cannot change formation.

  • Its Front Facing must be in contact with the enemy unit’s Target Facing (determined before the Pivot).

  • The centre of the Pursuing unit must move as short a distance as possible from its position before the Pivot, while still allowing a valid position following the Unit Spacing Rule after the Initial Align Move.

Afterwards, perform the Initial Align Move (see the Charge Phase chapter; in case of an Unaligned Charge, only perform the Initial Align Move, not the Special Align Move).

If there is not enough room to place the Pursuing unit in contact, treat the enemy unit as an Obstruction instead.


  • Battlefield Edge: if, after the Pivot, the Front Facing of the Pursuing unit would be in contact with (or outside) the Table Edge, the unit instead performs a Post-Combat Pivot, and then moves no further (i.e. ignore step 2.: Forward Ahead).

If it is not possible to perform this Post-Combat Pivot in a way that puts the unit in a valid end position, treat the Table Edge as an Obstruction instead.

  • Obstruction: if, after the Pivot, the Front Facing of the Pursuing unit would be in contact with an Obstruction, the unit instead Pivots so that it faces a direction as close as possible towards the same direction that the Pursued unit is Facing (or would be Facing, if it was removed as a casualty), while following the Unit Spacing rule.

The unit then moves no further.

  • Free to move: if, after the Pivot, the Front Facing of the Pursuing unit is not in contact with any other unit, Table Edge nor Obstruction, proceed to step 2: Forward Ahead.

2. Forward Ahead

Without moving the Pursuing unit, check what the first Obstacle, would be, within the rectangle formed by extending its Front Facing directly ahead of the unit a distance equal to the rolled Pursue Distance.

If more than one of these situations is applicable, apply only the uppermost one.

The Unit Spacing rule is ignored when doing this check and for all movement during Forward Ahead.

  • Enemy unit: if the first Obstacle would be the Unit Boundary of an enemy unit that did not Flee from the same Combat, the Pursuing unit Declares a Charge towards that unit, using its Pursue Distance roll as its Charge Range.

If there is more than one possible target, the Pursuing unit chooses which one to Charge.

The charged unit may not perform any Charge Reactions.

The Pursuing unit immediately performs a Charge Move towards the previously determined Target Facing, following all the normal Charge Move rules including: Align Moves, Unaligned Charge and Blocked Path if applicable.

If the Charge cannot be completed, the unit does not perform a Failed Charge Move, but treats the enemy unit as an Obstruction instead.

If the Pursuing unit joins a Combat that has already been fought or was created during this Melee Phase, it will be resolved in the next Melee Phase, with the Charging unit still counting as Charging.

If the Pursuing unit instead joins a Combat that was not created and has not been fought yet during the same Melee Phase, it will then fight again and can Pursue again this Phase.


  • Battlefield Edge: if the first Obstacle would be the Table Edge, move the unit straight forward until it touches the Table Edge, then immediately perform a Post-Combat Pivot.

  • Obstruction: if the first Obstacle would be an Obstruction, move the unit straight forward until just before it enters into contact with the Obstruction.

  • Free to move: if the Front Facing of the Pursuing unit would not come in contact with any Obstacle, move it straight forward by its Pursue Distance.

3. Valid Position?

At the end of the Pursue Move, check if the unit is in a valid position following the Unit Spacing rule.

It cannot be in contact with any enemy unit it did not Declare a Charge towards, but can be within 0.5" of Impassable Terrain or other units (such as friendly units that were part of the same Combat).

If the unit is not in a valid position, at the end of the move, backtrack it to its last valid position where it follows the Unit Spacing rule.

Example of two units Pursuing into the same enemy unit.a) Unit D loses the Combat, Breaks, and Flees 7". The owner of the winning units chooses to roll for unit A’s Pursue Distance first: 6", which is not enough to catch the Fleeing unit. Unit B’s Pursue Distance is 7", which is equal to or higher than unit D’s Flee Distance: the Fleeing unit is immediately removed as a casualty. Unit C’s Pursue Distance is 5".\
b) When checking which units will Charge an enemy unit during their Pursuit, before moving any Pursuing unit, it turns out that both unit A and unit B will Charge unit E: both units thus declare a Charge against unit E. Unit C will not Charge any enemy units.\
c) Now units A and B perform their Pursue Moves first. During this move, they can move through one another ignoring the Unit Spacing rule. Otherwise, they move using the normal rules for Charge Moves (ie. one Wheel allowed, Maximising Contact, etc.). In order to maximise the number of models and units in contact, unit A aligns its Front Facing with unit E’s, while unit B moves into corner to corner contact with unit E. Afterwards, unit C Pivots and moves its Pursue Distance straight forward.
rulebook-pursue_moves.title: Pursue Moves

rulebook-postcombat_pivots.def:
Any unit that was Engaged during this Round of Combat, but no longer is, and that did not perform a Pursue Move, can now perform a Post-Combat Pivot using the rules for a Pivot Manoeuvre.

(see the Movement Phase chapter.)

A unit that performs a Post-Combat Pivot, whatever its reason, cannot Declare any Charges in the Charge Phase of the next Player Turn. (If the next Player Turn is your opponent’s, the unit can Declare Charges as normal in your next Player Turn).
rulebook-postcombat_pivots.title: Post-Combat Pivots

rulebook-combat_reforms.def:
After all Fleeing and Pursuing units have been moved, any unit that is still Engaged in the Combat may attempt to perform a Combat Reform, with the following restrictions:

  • A unit Engaged on more than one of its Facings can never make a Combat Reform.

  • Any unit on the losing side of the Combat, as well as any unit Engaged on its Flank or Rear Facing, must pass a Command Test to be able to Combat Reform.

First, the Active Player declares which of their units will attempt to perform a Combat Reform, taking Command Test where needed. Then the Reactive Player declares which of their units will attempt to perform a Combat Reform, taking Command Test where needed.

Any units that are not perfectly aligned with the Target Facing of an enemy they are Engaged with at the time of declaring which units will attempt a Combat Reform, must attempt to do so, following the usual rules for Combat Reforms.

Once it has been established which units will perform a Combat Reforms, the Active Player chooses which player performs all of their Combat Reforms first; each player chooses in which order to perform their own units’ Combat Reforms.

When performing a Combat Reform, remove the unit from the Battlefield and place it back into contact with the enemy unit(s), following the rules below:

  • The unit can be placed in any viable formation, provided its number of files does not change by more than 2 .
  • At least as many models from both the reforming unit, and all units it was in contact with before the Combat Reform, must still be in contact with opposing models as before, but they do not have to be the same models.
  • Any Attachable Model, from either side, that was in contact with an enemy before the Combat Reform must remain in contact after the Combat Reform.

  • The unit can not move into contact with enemy units it was not in contact with before the Combat Reform.
  • The unit must maintain contact with the same enemy units as before the Combat Reform, and with the same Facings of those enemy units.
  • After having made its Combat Reform, the unit must be perfectly aligned against the enemy Facing it is Engaged with.

If multiple units are performing Combat Reforms, then the requirements mentioned above must be fulfilled at the end of all Combat Reforms by the first player, and then again at the end of all Combat Reforms by the second player, rather than after each individual unit has made its own Combat Reform.





Combat Reforms.a) At the end of a Round of Combat, unit A is Engaged with unit B and Unit C. Unit A performs a Combat Reform.\
b) Unit A has made its Combat Reform: the unit has added a file on its right flank, and the Character joined to the unit has changed position so as to be located on its front-right corner.
rulebook-combat_reforms.title: Combat Reforms

rulebook-after_the_game.def:
When the game ends, it is time to determine the winner. Do this by calculating Victory Points (VP) based on the following rules. You might also use custom rules for deciding a winner, if agreed upon by both players.

/section{battle_points}
rulebook-after_the_game.title: After the Game

rulebook-battle_points.def:
The winner of the game is determined by the number of Battle Points they score. Players always share a total of 20 Battle Points, making a 10-10 a draw and a 20-0 a decisive victory.
Battle Points can be scored in three ways:

  • Victory Points: the primary way to score Battle Points is by defeating enemy units, which gives you Victory Points (VP) (see below for details on how many VP units give).

  • Winning the Primary Objective: each player competes for the same Primary Objective, selected at the start of the game. The player who wins the Primary Objective scores 3 Battle Points, while the other player loses 3 Battle Points.

  • Completing Secondary Objectives: each player usually has one Secondary Objective, selected at the start of the game. For each Secondary Objective a player completes, they score 1 Battle Point, while their opponent loses 1 Battle Point (which means that if each player completes an equal number of Secondary Objectives, the score does not change).

If no outside source tells you how to use Secondary Objectives (e.g. tournament organiser, campaign rules, etc.), players should establish how much they want to focus on Secondary Objectives before the game. Consider the following guidelines:

  • In standard competitive games, Secondary Objectives are typically worth +1/-1 BP, as detailed in the table below.

  • For games focused on learning the core rules, it is recommended to ignore Secondary Objectives entirely.

  • Those seeking a more immersive, story-driven experience may opt to assign a higher value to Secondary Objectives, such as +5/-5 BP.

Players are encouraged to assign a value for Secondary Objectives corresponding to their desired level of competitive challenge and narrative engagement.



Scoring Victory Points


At the end of the game, each player earns Victory Points (VP) using the rules below.

  • Destroyed Units: you gain a number of VP equal to the full Points Cost (as stated on the Army List) of each enemy unit that has been removed as a casualty.

  • Shaken Units: you gain a number of VP equal to half the Points Cost (as stated on the Army List, and rounding fractions up) of each enemy Unit that is Shaken at the end of the game.

  • Decimated Units: you gain a number of VP equal to half the Points Cost (as stated on the Army List, and rounding fractions up) of each enemy unit that is Decimated at the end of the game (so that each enemy unit that is both Shaken and Decimated at the end of the game gives you its full Points Cost in VP).

  •

When calculating VP, Attachable Models are considered separately from the units they are joined to at the end of the game.
After summing all Victory Points for both players, calculate the difference between the amount gained by each player. Compare that difference to the Army Size, and check the table below to convert Victory Points to Battle Points. The player who scored the most Battle Points is the winner.

2black!5white
VP difference BP winner BP defeated
0 – 5% 10 10
>5 – 10% 11 9
>10 – 20% 12 8
>20 – 30% 13 7
>30 – 40% 14 6
>40 – 50% 15 5
>50% or more 16 4
Primary Objective +3 -3
Each Completed
Secondary
Objective		 +1* -1*


For example, at the end of a game with a 3000 points Army Size, player A scored 2054 VP and player B scored 1004 VP.

  • The difference is 1050, which is 35% of 3000. This means that player A receives 14 Battle Points, and player B, 6 Battle Points.

  • Player A won the Primary Objective, which modifies the result into 17-3.

  • Both players completed their Secondary Objective: the result is thus not further modified.



*If it was decided to increase the value of Secondary Objectives before the game, modify these values accordingly.
rulebook-battle_points.title: Battle Points

rulebook-measuring_distances.def:
Distances in The 9th Age: Fantasy Battlesare measured in inches, 1 inch being equal to 2.54 cm.

The game is normally played using 28 mm miniatures. At this scale, you may envision an inch representing roughly 1.5 metres in real life. In this case, a longbow’s 30" range translates to 45 metres.
You can also draw inspiration from history, seeing 1" as 10 metres instead. This gives the longbow a range of 300 metres: a standard battlefield of 72×48" table would then represent a real life area of 720×480 m, or roughly 50 football pitches. In medieval times, this would represent a battlefield where two forces with soldiers numbering from a few hundred to several thousand could meet.

The rules often refer to things being within a certain distance. When measuring distances, the closest points between objects are used, even if there are intervening elements.
Models or units are considered within range if the distance between their closest points is less than or equal to the given range.
Measurements are taken from and to the Unit Boundary of a unit (i.e. not necessarily the actual models).

Players are free to measure any distance at any time.

Range

Some effects, such as spells or shooting weapons, have a Range value (X"). This means that the effect can target things up to X inches away on the battlefield. Models or units are considered to be within range if the distance between their closest points is less than or equal to the given Range.

Long Range

For shooting weapons, we define targets as being in Long Range if they are further away than half of the weapon’s Range (but still within the maximum Range).

lineskip
Playing The 9th Age at different scales

lineskip

This game is designed to be compatible with changes in scale. The most common way to use this alternative mode of play is to play it at half-scale, where all distances are halved. This opens up possibilities for gameplay in more confined spaces, such as on ordinary kitchen tables, and entire armies can be neatly stored away in shoe boxes.

  • Distances: halve all measurements. This includes, but is not limited to, the battlefield dimensions, weapon and spell ranges, Mobility and Charge values, base sizes, area of effects, and more. Alternatively, you could decide to replace inches by centimetres (so that any distance of 10″ becomes 10 cm instead).

  • Models: use smaller models, designed to fit on the half base size. Typically, models suitable for this scale are in the 10 mm range.

  • Custom Measuring Devices: it is recommended that custom-made measuring devices are used, where all measurements are pre-halved. Such tools simplify rule referencing, eliminating the need for mental recalibration. Alternatively, if you have decided to replace inches by centimetres, you can measures all distances with a normal ruler, measuring centimetres instead of inches.
rulebook-measuring_distances.title: Measuring Distances

rulebook-dice.def:
This game uses six-sided dice for determining random outcomes. These dice are referred to as a D6.
The following different types dice rolls are used in the game:

  • Specific Value: when the result depends on whether the rolled value meets a specific value, this is noted with single quotation marks around the value, such as ‘1’.

  • Higher or Equal to: when the result depends on rolling equal to or higher than a specific target, this is written with a plus sign, such as 3+, meaning 3 or higher.

  • Multiple Dice: sometimes multiple dice are rolled together and, unless stated otherwise, their results are added together. This is indicated by a number preceding the dice type, such as 3D6, meaning roll three dice and add their results together (for an end result of 3 to 18).

  • Modified Dice Rolls: dice rolls can be modified in the following ways:

  • Adding a number, e.g. D6+2

  • Subtracting a number, e.g. D6-2

  • Multiplying with a number, e.g. D6×2

  • Maximised and Minimised Roll: for each instance of Maximised or Minimised, roll an additional dice, and discard the lowest or highest rolled dice before applying modifiers or adding any results.

  • Maximised: for each instance of Maximised, add a dice to the roll, and discard the dice that rolled the lowest result.

  • Minimised: for each instance of Minimised, add a dice to the roll, and discard the dice that rolled the highest result.

  • Both: if both Maximised and Minimised are applied to the same roll, each instance of one cancels out an instance of the other.

  • Rerolling Dice: certain effects allow for rerolling specific dice once.
This means picking up the dice that meet the reroll criteria and rolling them again, with the second result being final (i.e. a rerolled dice can never be rerolled again).

  • Rolling a D3: a D3 is a three-sided dice that will yield a result between 1 and 3. This can be simulated by halving the result of a D6 roll, rounding up (ie. ‘1’ and ‘2’ on a D6 count as 1; ‘3’ and ‘4’ on a D6 count as 2; ‘5’ and ‘6’ on a D6 count as 3).
rulebook-dice.title: Dice

rulebook-models_and_units.def:
In The 9th Age: Fantasy Battles, miniatures embody epic warriors, fierce monsters, and powerful spellcasters. Most warriors combine to form disciplined regiments called units, and several such units form the foundation of your army.

Model


A single gaming piece, placed on a base.
Each model has its own profile, which consists of various characteristics values, model rules, and equipment.
The profile reflects the capabilities of the model.

Rank-and-File model


Normal models in a unit.
All models, except Attachable Models (such as all Characters), are referred to as Rank-and-File models.

Base


The platform on which a model rests.
Bases are square or rectangular, and represent the area of the battlefield occupied by the model. In the game rules, the base is the only physical aspect of the model that matters.
Bases are measured in [front-width × side-length], e.g., 25×50 mm for most horse riders.

Unit


A group of one or more models that operate as a single entity, arranged in a rectangular formation. Models in a unit move and fight together, coordinating their actions on the battlefield.

When forming a unit of multiple models, the following conditions must be met to form a viable formation:

  • The models are placed in a tight rectangular (or square) formation, facing the same direction.

  • The unit cannot voluntarily have more ranks than files, unless the unit is wide enough to have a Proper Rank.

  • For units that are always considered to have 0 Proper Ranks, such as units entirely with Light Troops, apply this rule as if they could form Proper Ranks (e.g. a Height 1 unit entirely with Light Troops cannot have more ranks than files, unless it is at least five models wide).

  • Joining a unit with a Character or other Attachable model is a voluntary action.

  • The models are perfectly aligned and in contact with each other.

  • The width of the unit is determined by its first frontmost rank. No models may extend past this width.

  • Models not in the first rank must be positioned so that another model is directly in front of them, ensuring the entire front edge of their bases are in contact with the models in front of them.

  • All ranks within a unit must have the same width, except for the rear rank, which can be narrower.

  • It is acceptable for the rear rank to have gaps, as long as the models are aligned with those in the other ranks.

  • An Incomplete Rank refers to a rank with one or more missing models.

When a rule, ability, spell, or any other effect affects a unit, all models of the unit are affected, unless explicitly stated otherwise.

Unit Boundary


The Unit Boundary is an imaginary rectangle encompassing the outer edges of a unit.
A unit can never be inside the Boundary of another unit, unless they are explicitly allowed to temporarily be overlapping.
(Unit Boundaries can be represented by using unit trays of the right dimensions.)

Unit’s centre


A unit’s centre is the centre of its Unit Boundary.

Facings


A unit or a model has four Facings, that correspond to the edges of the Unit Boundary or the model’s base: a Front, a Rear, and two Flanks.

Arcs


A unit’s Arcs correspond to the area in front of the four Facings, divided by a straight line extending from the corners of the Unit Boundary at a 135° angle from the unit’s Facings.

Unit Arcs, Unit Facings, and Unit Boundariesa) This unit has 3 ranks and 5 files. The rear rank is incomplete and only contains 4 models. The Front, Flank, and Rear Arcs are defined by drawing lines from the corners of the Unit Boundary at a 135° angle from the unit’s Facings.\
b) The Unit Boundary is the area drawn around the outer edges of the unit (shaded red lines).
The Centre of the unit is the centre of the Unit Boundary.

c) A Unit Boundary cannot be inside another Unit Boundary, not even with parts that are not occupied by any models.

Proper Ranks


The number of models required to form a Proper Rank depends on the unit’s Height:

  • 5 models for Height 0-2.

  • 3 models for Height 3-4.

  • 1 model for Height 5.

Ranks and Files


Lines of models in the same unit that are side by side are called ranks.
Lines of models that are directly in front of and behind each other are called files.

Model Parts


Some models have multiple lines of Offensive Profiles.
Each line represents a different model part.

For example, a cavalry model consists of two model parts: a rider and its mount.
If a rule, ability, spell, or effect affects a model, then all its model parts are affected, unless stated otherwise.
During attacks or shooting, each model part uses its own characteristics and weapons.

/subsection{maintaining_a_viable_formation}
rulebook-models_and_units.title: Models and Units

rulebook-maintaining_a_viable_formation.def:
Whenever there are gaps in the formation of a unit, or incomplete ranks other than in the rear rank of a unit, the unit’s formation must be reformed into a viable formation.

Note: Except during a Round of Combat where Unit Boundaries and model placement in units are frozen. In this case, only follow the rules below when these are unfrozen.

When redistributing models to fill gaps and incomplete ranks in the unit’s formation, do so in the following priority order:

  • Move models from the rear rank.

  • Move models from ranks other than the front rank.

  • Move models from the front rank.

Avoid changing the number of files in the unit. If this is impossible (such as for a unit that only has a single rank), fill gaps by sliding all models from one side of the gap towards the other side.

Maintaining a Viable Formation in Combat


During a Round of Combat, the Unit Boundaries of all involved units are frozen, and models are not moved around inside the unit, not even to fill empty gaps inside their unit’s formation.

This applies from the start of each Round of Combat, until just before moving Fleeing and Pursuing units.

(See the Melee Phase chapter for details).

When determining the number of ranks or files a unit has, gaps are considered filled by models in back ranks as normal, potentially reducing the actual number of ranks or files.
rulebook-maintaining_a_viable_formation.title: Maintaining a Viable Formation

rulebook-unit_spacing.def:
Normally, units must maintain a distance of more than 1" from Impassable Terrain and other units both friends and enemies.

During ongoing moves, the Unit Spacing requirement is lowered to outside 0.5".

At the end a move a unit must be outside 1" again.

This means that units are allowed to come within 1", but still outside 0.5" of other units and Impassable Terrain during their moves.

A unit can still not come into contact, overlap with their bases, or voluntarily end a move within 1" of either
Impassable Terrain or other units.
The following moves are an exception to this::

Uncontrolled Move: Charge Moves, Failed Charge Moves, Flee Moves, Pursue Moves, Nudge to Maintain Contact,
Reform Moves, and when explicitly stated otherwise.

During an Uncontrolled Move a unit is allowed to move, and end within 0.5" of other units and Impassable Terrain, but cannot overlap with their bases, unless explicitly stated otherwise, such as it is in Pivot at the beginning of a Pursuit.

If a unit ends a move within 1" of one or more units or Impassable Terrain it may remain within 1" including within 0.5" of those units and Impassible Terrain, until it is outside 1" again.

Temporarily removing a unit from the battlefield, such as during a Reform or Pivot, does not count as moving outside 1", unless it is further away than 1" when placed back.

If a unit is ever forced to end a move in a invalid position, as determined by the type of move, or overlapping with a Unit Boundary or Impassible Terrain, backtrack the unit to its last valid position.
rulebook-unit_spacing.title: Unit Spacing

rulebook-characteristic_profiles.def:
Each unit entry contains three Characteristic Profiles: Global, Defensive, and Offensive. A higher value of a given Characteristic indicates that a model is more accomplished in that Characteristic. These values are used for various game mechanics like moving units and attacking with models.
Some model parts may not have specific values for certain Characteristics, such as the chassis of a chariot without Offensive Skill. These Characteristics are considered to be 0, and cannot be modified in any way.

Global Characteristics

Each model has three Global Characteristics. These Characteristics are common for all model parts on the same base (i.e. the whole model) and, in most situations, also shared for combined units.

ChaCharge SpeedThe higher the Charge Speed, the further the model can charge.
MobMobilityDetermines the distance that the model can move when doing a Move Manoeuvre.
DisDisciplineHow reliably the model follows orders.

  •

  •

Defensive Characteristics

Each model has four Defensive Characteristics. These Characteristics are common for all model parts on the same model.

HPHealth PointsA model is removed as a casualty when it loses this many Health Points.
DefDefensive SkillHow well the model avoids being hit in melee.
ResResilienceHow easily the model withstands blows.
ArmArmourA high Armour value means the model is able to deflect wounds that should have put it out of Combat.
Offensive Characteristics

If a model has more than one model part, each model part has its own set of Offensive Characteristics. Each model part has five Offensive Characteristics:

AgiAgilityModel parts with a higher Agility strike first in melee.
AttAttack ValueThe number of times the model part can strike in a Round of Combat.
OffOffensive SkillHow good the model part is at scoring hits in melee.
StrStrengthHow easily the model part can wound enemy models.
APArmour PenetrationHow well the model part can penetrate the Armour of enemy models.

Random Characteristics
Some model parts have random values for one or more Characteristics, such as Attack Value D6+1.

Roll for the value each time immediately before it is used.
In the case of an Offensive Characteristic, the rolled value is used for all simultaneous attacks from that model part.
When several model parts in the same unit have a random value for a Characteristic, roll separately for each model part.
rulebook-characteristic_profiles.title: Characteristic Profiles

rulebook-model_height.def:
In the game, each model is assigned a Height, which is represented by a number ranging from 0 to 5.

The higher the number, the larger the model’s vertical size is. This is important for Line of Sight purposes, but also affects the model’s ability to form Proper Ranks, how many Restricted Attacks it can perform, and how many dice it rolls for its Dangerous Terrain Tests.




1whiteblack!5
Height 0 1 2 3 4 5
Required width to form a Proper Rank 5 models 5 models 5 models 3 models 3 models 1 model
Number of Proper Ranks needed to be Solid 4 4 3 2 2 2
Number of Standard Melee Attacks that can be done as Restricted Attacks 0 attack 1 attack 2 attacks 3 attacks 4 attacks 5 attacks


Some rules may reference a unit’s Height or a Unit Boundary’s Height, such as for determining the number of models needed to form a Proper Ranks in units composed of models of different Heights.

In such cases, the unit’s Height is determined by the largest group of models with the same Height.
In situations where there is a tie, use the smallest Height.


Size comparison between models. From upper right to lower left:

  • Great Green Idol, Height 5

  • Giant, Height 5

  • Iron Orc Chariot, Height 4

  • Troll, Height 3

  • Feral Orc Marauder, Height 2

  • Veteran Orc, Height 1

  • Goblin Rabble, Height 1

  • Grotlings, Height 0
rulebook-model_height.title: Model Height

rulebook-line_of_sight.def:
A model can draw Line of Sight to its target (a point, a model, or a Unit Boundary) if you can draw a line from the model to its target in the model’s Front Arc and without crossing Line of Sight-blocking Obstructions, such as:

  • Opaque Terrain (see the Terrain chapter).

  • Models in another unit whose Height is equal or greater than to both the model’s and its target’s.

A model that is not in the front rank of a unit, instead draws its Line of Sight from a point on the Front Facing of its unit that is directly in front of it (typically from the Front Facing from a model directly in front of it).

All of the following conditions must be fulfilled:

  • The line must be a straight line with its starting point on the model’s Front Facing.

  • The line can only deviate at most 45° from the straight forward direction of the model (this means that the line cannot be drawn outside the model’s own Front Arc).

  • Models never block Line of Sight to or from other models within the same unit.

  • The line between the model and the target does not cross over any Obstruction, such as:

  • Any Opaque Terrain.

  • The base of a model in another unit whose Height is equal or greater than both the model’s and its target’s.

  • A Unit Boundary whose Height is equal or greater than both the model’s and its target’s.

A unit is considered to have Line of Sight to a target if at least one model in the unit can draw Line of Sight to it.

For the purpose of drawing Line of Sight to or from a point on the Battlefield, that point is considered to be of Height 0.

Drawing Line of Sight.The area within which the single model unit D can draw Line of Sight is marked.

  • Unit B is within Line of Sight.

  • Unit A is within Line of Sight, as unit D can draw Line of Sight to the Boundary of unit A, even though that part of A’s Unit Boundary is not occupied by any models.

  • Unit C is not within Line of Sight, as the Impassable Terrain Feature is an Opaque Terrain, therefore blocking Line of Sight from unit D to unit C.
rulebook-line_of_sight.title: Line of Sight

rulebook-properties.def:
Behold, a rare and unique quality.
Units, attacks and spells can have key words called Properties attached to them. Properties describe the unit’s origin, allegiance, elemental effects, equipment, or other defining attributes. Properties can always be identified by their names being displayed in grey and italics.

Properties are rules that do not possess any innate or direct effects. Instead, Properties are only used as triggers for other rules. For example, a rule might restrict Characters from joining a unit unless it possesses the right Clan Property.
rulebook-properties.title: Properties

rulebook-duration_of_effects.def:
Certain abilities may provide time-limited additional effects to models.
Generally such effects immediately cease to work when a model is removed.

The following key-words are used to denote the durations of such effects.

  • Instant: the effects are applied once, then immediately end.

  • Round of Combat: the effects last until the end of the Round of Combat in which they were applied.

  • One Phase: the effects last until the end of the Phase in which they were applied.

  • End of Combat: the effects last until the model is Unengaged.

  • End of Turn: the effects last until the end of the Player Turn in which they were applied.

  • One Turn: the effects last until the start of the next same Phase as when the effects were applied, of the same player (e.g if the effects were applied during the Magic Phase of Player A, then they end at the start of the next Magic Phase of Player A.)

  • Permanent: the effects last until the end of the game, or until a specific condition is met as described in the effect.

Permanent effects do not end when if the model applying the effect is removed as a casualty.

  • One use only: these effects can only be used once per game. Each One use only effect will describe when it can be used (or activated).

-1

Extended Effects and Combined Units

It can happen that a unit affected by effects with an extended duration (such as One Turn or Permanent) becomes divided into multiple units – the most common example of this is when an Attachable Model leaves the unit that it was joined to.
When this happens, the effects keep applying to each of those elements for the given duration. See Attachable Models chapter for Continuous effects.

An Attachable Model who joins a unit affected by an effect, or a unit that is joined by an Attachable Model affected by an effect, do not become affected themselves.

Simultaneous Effects

When multiple effects occur at the same time, the Active Player resolves their effects first.

Each player decides the order in which they resolve their own simultaneous effects.
rulebook-duration_of_effects.title: Duration of Effects

rulebook-modifiers.def:
Modifiers can affect the values of Characteristics, dice rolls, or other numerical values in the game. They can set values, add or subtract from them, multiply or divide them, and are applied in the following order:

  • A Value Set to a Fixed Number: when a value or a roll is set to a specific number, replace the original value or roll with that number. When a value is set to at least a number, do not set the value if it would result in a reduction to the value.

  • Multiplication and Division: values or rolls can be multiplied or divided by a given number.

  • Addition and Subtraction: values or rolls can be modified by adding or subtracting a given number to or from them.

  • If a limit is defined in the rule, apply the modification after other operations that do not define a limit, and only up to that limit. For example, if a Charging model is in contact with a Wall and rolls to hit towards an opponent with Distracting (1), first apply the -1 from being in contact with a Wall, then apply the -1 from Distracting, unless the model already hits on 5+.

  • Difficulties (ie., things in the form of X+) can also be modified by addition or subtraction. To work out how a modifier applies to a difficulty of X+ we use the following formula: [difficulty score] – [modifier] = [new difficulty score]. For example, an attack wounding on 4+ with a +1 to-wound modifier, now wounds on 3+.

  • Always and Never: some rolls always or never succeed or fail on certain results, whereas some Characteristics always or never have a certain value or range of values.

  • Restrictions: after applying all modifications, certain limits apply to some Characteristics:

  • Use only whole numbers: round any fractions up.

  • No Characteristics can be below 0, not even temporarily. Set any value below 0 to 0.

  • Armour can never be higher than 6, not even temporary.

  • Discipline and Agility can never be higher than 10, not even temporary.

  • A Melee Attack always hits on a ‘6’, and always fails on a ‘1’.

When multiple modifiers have the same priority step, apply them in the order that results in the lowest value, or the lowest chance of success.
rulebook-modifiers.title: Modifiers

rulebook-definition_of_a_move.def:
Some rules may be triggered by a unit performing a Move, which is one of the following actions:

  • Move Manoeuvres (Advance Move, March Move, Reform Move) and any rule that refers to any of these, such as Vanguard Moves and Magical Moves.

  • Charge Move (including the Align Move) and Failed Charge Move.

  • Flee Move and Pursue Move (including Overrun, and Random Movement).

  • Combat Reform and Post-combat Pivot.
rulebook-definition_of_a_move.title: Definition of a Move

rulebook-contact_between_objects.def:
Two objects, such as bases, Unit Boundaries, Terrain Features, and so on, are considered to be in contact if:

  • They touch one another:

  • Along a line (e.g. two rectangular bases contacting each other along their front).

  • At a single point (e.g. corner to corner contact between units).

  • One object is overlapping another. An object is considered to be inside another if it is either partially or fully inside that other object.

Contact between Models and Units


  • Two or more units are in contact if their Unit Boundaries touch each other (including corner to corner contact).

  • Two or more models are in contact if their bases touch each other (including corner to corner contact, and including across empty gaps in a unit, see below).

  • A model is in contact with a unit if it is in contact with that Unit’s Boundary.

Contact between Models across Gaps

Incomplete ranks or Characters with Mismatching Base may cause gaps between opposing models whose units are in contact. Two opposing models are considered to be in contact with each other across such gaps if you can draw a straight line:

  • from one model to the other (including corner to corner),

  • that is perpendicular to both units’ Engaged Facings.

A model is considered not to be in contact across a gap if its entire Facing that is opposite the enemy model is itself in contact with a friendly model.
