rulebook-contact_between_objects.title: Contact between Objects

rulebook-battlefield_edge.def:
The Battlefield Edge represents the boundaries of the game.

A unit is allowed to temporarily and partially move off the Battlefield during a Movement Manoeuvre or Charge Move, with the following restrictions:

  • The unit’s Front Facing must remain entirely on the board at all times, except during Align Moves.

  • The unit must finish any movement with its Unit Boundary entirely on the Battlefield.
rulebook-battlefield_edge.title: Battlefield Edge

rulebook-attacks.def:
Each attempt to kill an enemy first requires you to land a blow, and second, for the blow to prove harmful. And of course, it must not be blocked by armour or other defences.

/section{attacks}/section{attack_sequence}/section{saves}/section{losing_health_points_br_and_casualties}

Attacks in the game can be performed using Melee Weapons, Shooting Weapons, spells, or unique abilities. This section explains the general process of performing attacks and determining their success in causing damage to their targets.

Most sources of damage are categorised as attacks, which are divided into:

  • Melee Attacks: attacks made in the Melee Phase, from models towards a unit it is Engaged in Combat with.

  • Standard Melee Attacks: the most common type of Melee Attack, where model parts perform a number of attacks primarily based on their Attack Value, are called Standard Melee Attacks.

  • Ranged Attacks: all attacks that are not Melee Attacks are considered Ranged Attacks.

  • Shooting Attacks: the rules sometimes refer to Shooting Attacks or attacks made by Shooting Weapons. Shooting Attacks are a type of Ranged Attacks.
rulebook-attacks.title: Attacks

rulebook-attack_sequence.def:
When conducting an attack, follow this sequence:
1 - The attacker allocates its attacks to a target.
2 - Determine the number of hits. If at least one hit is caused, proceed.
3 - The attacker rolls to wound. If successful, proceed.
4 - The defender rolls Armour Saves. If failed, proceed.
5 - The defender rolls Special Saves. If failed, proceed.
6 - The defender suffers unsaved wounds, loses Health Points and removes casualties.
7 - The defender takes Panic Tests if necessary.

Complete each step for all simultaneous attacks, such as all Shooting Attacks from a single unit or all Melee Attacks at a specific Agility Step, before proceeding to the next step.

/subsection{allocating_attacks}/subsection{determining_the_number_of_hits}/subsection{towound_rolls}
rulebook-attack_sequence.title: Attack Sequence

rulebook-determining_the_number_of_hits.def:
Some attacks require a to-hit roll, while other attacks hit automatically, inflicting a fixed or random number of hits.

The rules for how attacks hit are described for each attack. The most common type of to-hit rolls can be found in the Shooting Phase and Melee Phase chapters.

Whenever an effect inflicts a random number of hits on more than one unit, roll for the number of hits separately for each unit, unless specifically stated otherwise.
rulebook-determining_the_number_of_hits.title: Determining the Number of Hits

rulebook-towound_rolls.def:
Once you have hit your target, you must wound it in order to potentially cause harm.

To determine if a hit successfully wounds the target, roll a D6 for each hit.

The required roll to wound depends on the difference between the attack’s Strength and the defender’s Resilience, as indicated in the table below.
A roll of ‘6’ always succeeds, while a roll of ‘1’ always fails.

The attacker rolls for each hit to determine if it wounds the target. A successful to-wound roll results in a wound.

If the attack does not have a Strength, refer to the specific rules provided for that particular attack.




Difference
Str - Res		 Required roll to wound
2 or more 2+
1 3+
0 4+
-1 5+
-2 or less 6+





Str 1 Str 2 Str 3 Str 4 Str 5 Str 6 Str 7 Str 8 Str 9 Str 10
Res 1 4+ 3+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+
Res 2 5+ 4+ 3+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+
Res 3 6+ 5+ 4+ 3+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+
Res 4 6+ 6+ 5+ 4+ 3+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+
Res 5 6+ 6+ 6+ 5+ 4+ 3+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+
Res 6 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 5+ 4+ 3+ 2+ 2+ 2+
Res 7 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 5+ 4+ 3+ 2+ 2+
Res 8 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 5+ 4+ 3+ 2+
Res 9 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 5+ 4+ 3+
Res 10 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 6+ 5+ 4+
rulebook-towound_rolls.title: To-Wound Rolls

rulebook-saves.def:
When wounds are inflicted on a unit, there are two types of saves that the defender can make to potentially negate the damage: Armour Saves and Special Saves.

When taking saves, the owner of the attacked model rolls a D6 and compares it with the needed score to pass the save.

See the details below for how to pass Armour Saves and Special Saves.

If successful, the wound is ignored. First roll Armour Save, and then, if this is not passed, roll the Special Save (provided the model has one).
If the Special Save is failed, or the model does not have a Special Save, a wound is inflicted. Proceed to Losing Health Points and Casualties.

/subsection{armour_saves}/subsection{special_saves}
rulebook-saves.title: Saves

rulebook-armour_saves.def:
The defender rolls Armour Saves by rolling a D6 for each wound, and comparing the result with the model’s Armour Value, reduced by the Attack’s Armour Penetration.

The modified Armour value describes the number of sides on a D6, counting down from the highest value, that will result in a successful roll see the tables below.

If the Armour Save is successful, the wound is ignored.
A roll of ‘1’ is always a failure.

Arm – AP Armour Save Roll
5 or above 2+
4 3+
3 4+
2 5+
1 6+
0 Cannot be passed




AP 0 AP 1 AP 2 AP 3 AP 4 AP 5 AP 6
Arm 0 N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A
Arm 1 6+ N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A
Arm 2 5+ 6+ N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A
Arm 3 4+ 5+ 6+ N/A N/A N/A N/A
Arm 4 3+ 4+ 5+ 6+ N/A N/A N/A
Arm 5 2+ 3+ 4+ 5+ 6+ N/A N/A
Arm 6 2+ 2+ 3+ 4+ 5+ 6+ N/A



For example, Armour 3, means that ‘6’, ‘5’, and ‘4’ would be successful Armour Save rolls. If the model is attacked by Armour Penetration 1, its Armour is reduced to Armour 2, which now means that ‘6’ and ‘5’ are successful Armour Save rolls.

This is equivalent with using the formula below to determine the required roll to negate the wound:
7 – (Defender’s Armour)

+ (Attacker’s Armour Penetration)

Combined Armour

Each model has a base Armour value in its profile, and some models may have additional equipment, rules, or be under the effect of spells that modify their Armour values.
Different sources of Armour can be combined, adding up to the total combined Armour.

For example, a model with a base Armour of 3 that is under the effect of a spell that grants +1 Armour, has a combined Armour of 4. When wounded by an attack with Armour Penetration 1, the needed Armour Save roll would be ‘4’, ‘5’, or ‘6’ (or 4+).
rulebook-armour_saves.title: Armour Saves

rulebook-special_saves.def:
If a wound is not saved by the Armour Save, the defender may negate the attack, even an Unmodifiable one, with its Special Save, if it has one. Special Saves work like Armour Saves, except they are unaffected by Armour Penetration.

A natural roll of ‘1’ or ‘2’ is always a failure.

There are two types of Special Saves: Aegis and

Regeneration, each explained in detail in the Model Rules section.

A model is only allowed to roll one Special Save roll for each attack.
rulebook-special_saves.title: Special Saves

rulebook-losing_health_points_br_and_cas.def:
When a model suffers an unsaved wound, it immediately loses a Health Point, which can result in models being removed as casualties.

Sometimes rules state to a model or unit loses X Health Points. This is to be considered identical with suffers X hits that wound automatically and allow no saves of any type.

When a specific model in a unit loses X HP, the HP losses must be allocated onto that model.

When a unit loses X HP due to its own rule or the rule of its army (such as Supernal, Unstable), all HP losses are assigned and rolled out by its owner.

/subsection{health_pools}/subsection{casualties}/subsection{losing_the_last_health_point}/subsection{casualties_when_engaged}
rulebook-losing_health_points_br_and_cas.title:
Losing Health Points
and Casualties

rulebook-health_pools.def:
Health Points are organised into Health Pools.
A unit’s Rank-and-File models form a collective Health Pool, while any other models joined to the unit each have their own separate Health Pool.
rulebook-health_pools.title: Health Pools

rulebook-casualties.def:
Each unsaved wound reduces the Health Pool by 1 Health Point.

  • If the models in the attacked Heath Pool have 1 Health Point each, remove one model for each Health Point lost.

  • If the models have more than 1 Health Point each, remove entire models whenever possible. Keep track of any lost Health Points that are not enough to remove a whole model, as they will be taken into account for future attacks.
For example, a unit of 10 Trolls (3 Health Points each) loses 7 Health Points: remove two whole models (6 Health Points), leaving 1 lost Health Point, which is kept track of. Later, this unit loses 2 Health Points, which is enough to remove a single Troll, since 1 Health Point was lost from the previous attack.

When there are more Health Point losses than there are Health Points in a Health Pool, the excess losses are ignored. In situations where simultaneous attacks from different model parts, models, or units cause excess Health Point losses, the owner of the attacking models decides which attacks caused the excess losses (if relevant).

When enough Health Points are lost to remove models, do so from as far back in the unit as possible.

In certain situations, additional nuances for casualty removal are needed. In such cases, follow the procedure below:

  • Remove models from as far back in the unit as possible.

  • Remove models one by one, in any chosen order.

  • When casualties are removed from the first rank, remove models equally from both sides of the unit, one by one.
This applies only to each batch of simultaneous losses.

  • If a model of a different Health Pool is in a position that would normally be removed as a casualty, remove the next eligible model of the attacked Health Pool and redistribute the models in the unit into a viable formation (see Maintaining a Viable Formation in the Definitions and Terminology chapter).

If the removal of casualties would lead to a non-viable unit formation, such as gaps being created in ranks other than the last, follow the procedure described in the Reference Handbook
under Maintaining a Viable Formation, in the Definitions and Terminology chapter.
rulebook-casualties.title: Casualties

rulebook-losing_the_last_health_point.def:
When a model loses its last Health Point, it is removed as a casualty.
When the last model from a unit loses its last Health Point, the unit is removed as a casualty.

Certain effects are triggered by models being removed as a casualty, while others are set off by models losing their last Health Point or reaching 0 Health Points.
Losing the last Health Point does not apply to situations in which a model is directly removed as a casualty, without actually losing any Health Points (such as units leaving the Battlefield while doing a Flee Move, or being removed as a casualty after Breaking from Combat).

Whenever a model that applies any effect to other elements in the game is removed as a casualty, unless specifically stated otherwise, that effect ends immediately.
This also applies to effects that have a specified duration, such as activated effects with Duration: One Turn.
rulebook-losing_the_last_health_point.title: Losing the Last Health Point

rulebook-casualties_when_engaged.def:
When an Engaged unit suffers Casualties outside the Melee Phase, where Boundaries are frozen, apply the following rules:


  • When casualties would be removed from the first rank, instead of removing models equally from both sides of the unit, remove models from the side that avoids making Engaged units lose Contact with each other.

  • If unavoidable, prioritize creating gaps where as many units as possible can be nudged back into contact.

  • If gaps are created between units, follow the rules under Nudge Units to Maintain Contact (see the Melee Phase chapter).
rulebook-casualties_when_engaged.title: Casualties when Engaged

rulebook-characters.def:
A Character is a significant and unique individual in the army, often possessing special abilities, skills, or powers that set them apart from regular troops. Characters are a special type of models that are recruited from the Characters Army Category of an Army Book.

Unless stated otherwise, Characters follow the rules for Attachable Models, which means they can join other units.

/section{make_way}/section{general}/section{battle_standard_bearer}/section{leadership_skills}/section{character_mounts}
rulebook-characters.title: Characters

rulebook-make_way.def:
It can happen that a Character’s unit is Engaged in Combat, while that Character is not itself in contact with any enemy model. When this happens, the Character may be eligible for a Make Way move.

To be able to perform a Make Way move, the Character:

  • Must be in the first rank of its unit.

  • Must not be in contact with any enemy models.

  • Must not have a Mismatching Base.

̉Make Way moves are performed when Choosing Equipment and Abilities.

The Character switches positions with a Rank-and-File model (or models) in its unit that is in contact with an enemy.

The Character must end up in a valid position.

Normally this means that the Character can only swap positions with models in the Front rank.
rulebook-make_way.title: Make Way

rulebook-battle_standard_bearer.def:
An army may include a Battle Standard Bearer.

This upgrade is Legendary.

A Battle Standard Bearer gives +1 Combat Resolution to its side in combat, and gains Rally Around the Flag (see Model Rules).

If the model has the option to buy Magic Items, it is allowed to buy a Banner Enchantment.
rulebook-battle_standard_bearer.title: Battle Standard Bearer

rulebook-leadership_skills.def:
30
60
Recruiting officerfreeAny unit in your Army List that is not a single model unit (i.e. unit entries without unit size Single model) may take the following upgrade:\Fresh Meat (35 pts/unit): the unit gains Exclusive, changes its Maximum Points Cost to 800 points, and increases its maximum unit size by +20%, rounding fractions up.
\
For example, a unit entry with unit size 10–24 models would increase that maximum by +4.8 models, rounded to 5, resulting in a new limit of 10–29 models.
rulebook-leadership_skills.title: Leadership Skills

rulebook-character_mounts.def:
When a Character selects a mount from the options available to it, the following rules apply to the combined model of a rider and its mount:

  • Height and Base: use the Mount’s Height and base.

  • Offence Characteristics: the rider and the mount each use their own Offensive Characteristics, Weapons and Attack Attributes.

  • Defence and Global Characteristics: the combined model has a single set of Global and Defensive Characteristics and Model Rules.

  • Generally, the values from the mount’s profile are used.

Modifiers to the rider’s Characteristics have no impact on the Global and Defence Characteristics of the mount, unless specifically mentioned otherwise, or in of the following:

  • If a value in the mount’s profile is indicated as C, the corresponding value from the Character’s profile is used instead, including any modifiers to it.

  • If a value is written as C+X, increase the Character’s value by X, and use that value as the whole model’s.

  • If a value is written as C–X, decrease the Character’s value by X, and use that value as the whole model´s.

  • For example, a Character with Arm 2 is using a Shield (+1 Arm) while mounted on a Dragon with Arm 4: the combined model’s Armour value is still only 4 (the Dragon’s).

If the same Character is instead mounted on a Warhorse with Arm C+2, the model’s Armour value is 5 (2+1+2).


  • Model Rules: Model Rules also follow the principles described above, with the following specifications:

  • Attack Attributes and Weapons are applied only to the specific model part that has those rules.

  • Other Model Rules are applied to the combined model as a whole.

  • For example, a Character with Distracting, Lethal Strike is mounted on a Warhorse.

The horse cannot benefit from Lethal Strike: since it is an Attack Attribute, it applies only to attacks from a single model part, the Character itself.

However, Distracting is neither an Attack Attribute nor a Weapon, and is therefore applied to the entire combined model.
rulebook-character_mounts.title: Character Mounts

rulebook-attachable_models.def:
Attachable Models are models that have the flexibility to join other units as well as to operate by themselves. The most common type of Attachable Models are Characters. All Characters are Attachable Models, unless mentioned otherwise. In addition to Characters, a few other models may be defined as Attachable, such as those with the Model Rule War Platform.

/section{lone_attachable_models}/section{combined_units}
rulebook-attachable_models.title: Attachable Models

rulebook-lone_attachable_models.def:
Attachable Models can operate as a unit consisting of just themselves - a single model unit.

In this case, the normal rules for units apply to them.
rulebook-lone_attachable_models.title: Lone Attachable Models

rulebook-combined_units.def:
Attachable Models that join other units form a Combined Unit.

Once an Attachable Model has joined a unit, they are considered part of the unit for all rules purposes, unless specified otherwise.

/subsection{joining_other_units}/subsection{moving_combined_units}/subsection{placement_within_a_combined_unit}/subsection{leaving_a_combined_unit}
rulebook-combined_units.title: Combined Units

rulebook-joining_other_units.def:
Attachable Models can join other units either by Deploying inside and simultaneously with the unit, or by moving into contact with the unit through a Move Manoeuvre.

Upon joining a unit, the unit that was joined cannot move further in the same Phase.

A Attachable Model ignores the Unit Spacing rule with regards to the unit it is about to join, and must have enough movement to reach its final and valid position within the unit, which normally means it must be able to reach its Front rank.

During the Player Turn in which an Attachable Model joins the unit, the Attachable Model and the unit are treated individually for the purpose of determining which model has moved or performed a March Move or not.

Units that are Shaken or Engaged in Combat cannot be joined by an Attachable Model.

The Attachable Model can choose any valid position it can reach with its move.

This includes moving through the unit it joins, maybe displacing other Attachable Models. Displaced Rank-and-File models are placed in rear ranks.

If the unit has a single rank, the Attachable Model or the displaced models can alternatively be placed on the side of the unit, forming a new file.
rulebook-joining_other_units.title: Joining other units

rulebook-moving_combined_units.def:
Combined Units are moved as a group, following the normal rules for moving units.

An Attachable Model can move within its unit’s formation by swapping places with other models, as long as the resulting position is still a valid one (generally in the Front rank).

This can be done as part of the following moves:

  • Move Manoeuvres (Advance, March, and Reform Moves)

  • Pivots, including Post-combat Pivots and Post-Rally Pivots.

Note: this does not include Pivots occurring as part of a Flee or Pursue Move (including Overruns).

  • Combat Reforms
Remember that additional restrictions apply to which positions are valid – see the Melee Phase chapter.

Attachable Models are not allowed to move within their unit’s formation under any other circumstances, such as when Charging, Aligning, Pursuing or performing a Flee Move.
rulebook-moving_combined_units.title: Moving Combined Units

rulebook-placement_within_a_combined_uni.def:
Unless stated otherwise, Attachable Models must be placed in the front rank of the unit they are joined to.

If this is not possible (e.g. due to the Front rank already being filled with other Attachable Models), they must instead be placed as far forward as possible in the unit.

/subsubsection{matching_bases}/subsubsection{mismatching_bases}/subsubsection{units_made_of_only_attachable_models}/subsubsection{rankandfile_models_in_a_combined_brunit_wiped_out}
rulebook-placement_within_a_combined_uni.title: Placement within a Combined Unit

rulebook-matching_bases.def:
In Combined Units with both Attachable Models and Rank-and-File models, an Attachable Model is considered to have a Matching Base if the size of its base is the same as that of the Rank-and-File models in the unit, or if the size of its base is a multiple of the size of the Rank-and-File models’ bases in the unit.

E.g. a 40×40 mm base in a unit where every model has a 20x20 mm base.
Models on Matching Bases are placed inside the formation of the unit they join, normally displacing another model or models. If the model has a larger base than the Rank-and-File models, it counts as occupying all ranks its base covers for Proper Ranks calculations.

-11.30tercioAngle.png

If a model with a Matching Base has a longer base than the Rank-and-File models, it is possible that the unit finds itself with more than one incomplete rank, if all incomplete ranks consist entirely of models with such bases (e.g. the rear parts of long bases of models such as War Platform can form several incomplete ranks).

A model cannot join a unit with more than one rank if its base is wider than the unit is, nor can a unit Reform into a formation narrower than any model joined to it.
rulebook-matching_bases.title: Matching Bases

rulebook-mismatching_bases.def:
Any base that is not a Matching Base is considered a Mismatching Base, such as an Attachable Model on a 40×40 mm base in a unit where Rank-and-File models have 25×50 mm bases. A model with a Mismatching Base is always placed in contact to the side of the unit, aligned with its Front.

Each unit can only include two models with Mismatching Bases, one on each side.

These models are considered to be only in the Front rank, and are not counted when determining the number of models in each rank for Proper Ranks. They form a separate file of one model each.

\

Matching and Mismatching Bases.a) A Character on a Mismatching Base is placed next to the unit. Characters on Matching Bases are placed inside the unit, as far forwards as possible. This unit is considered to have 6 files and 4 ranks.\
b) When an Attachable Model joins the unit, the small Attachable Model in the second rank must be moved to the side in order to have all Attachable Models as far forwards as possible.
rulebook-mismatching_bases.title: Mismatching Bases

rulebook-units_made_of_only_attachable_m.def:
For Combined Units consisting entirely of Attachable Models, Matching or Mismatching Bases are determined differently since there are no Rank-and-File models. In such a case, the owner of the unit decides, when the unit is first formed, which model’s base to use in place of Rank-and-File models. Models with the same base, or bases that are a multiple of it, are then considered Matching.

If the chosen model leaves the unit or is removed as a casualty, a new model must be chosen as reference for Matching/Mismatching Bases. If possible, this choice must be made so that as few models as possible change their status regarding Matching or Mismatching (normally this means choosing a model with the same base as the model that left the unit).
rulebook-units_made_of_only_attachable_m.title: Units Made of Only Attachable Models

rulebook-rankandfile_models_in_a_combine.def: When all the Rank-and-File models in a combined unit are wiped out, but there are still Attachable Models left, they form a smaller combined unit. This smaller unit is treated as the same unit for effects and Panic Tests.
rulebook-rankandfile_models_in_a_combine.title:
Rank-and-File Models in a Combined
Unit Wiped Out

rulebook-leaving_a_combined_unit.def:
Attachable Models can leave a combined unit with a Move Manoeuvre, or by Charging out of it, assuming they are able to move freely.
This means Attachable Models can not leave units while Engaged in Combat, if their unit has already moved, or if they are Shaken.

Continuous effects (i.e. all effects without a specified duration, such as most Banner Enchantments) continue to affect all parts of the previously Combined Unit.
Duration: One Phase.

/subsubsection{move_manoeuvres_out_of_a_unit}/subsubsection{charging_out_of_a_unit}
rulebook-leaving_a_combined_unit.title: Leaving a Combined Unit

rulebook-move_manoeuvres_out_of_a_unit.def:
To leave a unit, move the Attachable Model out of the unit using a Move Manoeuvre. Attachable Models ignore the Unit Spacing rule with regards to the unit they are leaving.

The unit that is left behind is not considered to have moved, and is free to perform its own move later in the Phase.
rulebook-move_manoeuvres_out_of_a_unit.title: Move Manoeuvres out of a Unit

rulebook-charging_out_of_a_unit.def:
An Attachable Model in a Combined Unit may Declare a Charge on its own during the Charge Phase, i.e. Charging out of the unit and leaving the unit behind.

When doing this, apply the following rules:

  • Use the position of the Combined Unit for determining which Facing of the enemy unit the Charge is Declared towards, and for determining the Flee direction if the Charged unit performs a Flee! Charge Reaction.

  • Use the Attachable Model for determining Line of Sight and distance to the enemy unit.

  • Attachable Models ignore the Unit Spacing rule with regards to the unit they are leaving.

  • The unit itself (including other Attachable Models in the unit) cannot Declare Charges in the same Player Turn.

  • If the Charge is successful, move the Attachable Model out of the unit by Charging as normal.

If there is not enough room to physically move the model out of the unit, the Charge cannot be Declared.

  • If the Charge is not successful, the Attachable Model makes a Failed Charge Move out of the unit.

If the Failed Charge Move is too short to place the Attachable Model outside 1" of the Combined Unit, the Attachable Model remains in the Combined Unit, and the entire Combined Unit performs the Failed Charge Move instead.

  • Once the Attachable Model Declares a Charge, it is treated as a separate unit. This means that the model uses its own Charge Speed.
rulebook-charging_out_of_a_unit.title: Charging out of a Unit

rulebook-terrain.def:
Each battlefield is unique, with opportunities and challenges presented by the lie of the land. The ability to use both geographical features and man-made structures to your advantage can make all the difference. Some landscapes can be so treacherous that your forces may even perish if they lack sufficient caution.

/section{terrain_rules}/section{terrain_features}
rulebook-terrain.title: Terrain

rulebook-terrain_rules.def:
Terrain represents distinct areas on the battlefield that introduce additional rules that affect models within or interacting with it. These areas are typically represented by modelled terrain that are placed on the board.

The most common Terrain Features in the game are explained below.

In addition, rules for more Terrain Features can be found in the Season Pack.

/subsection{open_terrain}/subsection{covering_terrain}/subsection{dangerous_terrain}/subsection{disruptive_terrain}/subsection{opaque_terrain}
rulebook-terrain_rules.title: Terrain Rules

rulebook-open_terrain.def: Open Terrain normally does not have any effect on Line of Sight, Cover, or movement. All parts of the board that are not covered by any kind of Terrain Features are Open Terrain.
rulebook-open_terrain.title: Open Terrain

rulebook-covering_terrain.def:
Covering Terrain contributes to Cover when drawing Line of Sight through it.

The bracket (X) indicates whether the terrain contributes to Soft Cover or Hard Cover.

Certain Terrain Features (such as Ruins, Fields) only count as Covering Terrain for units in contact with them.
Ignore any Terrain Feature the shooter itself is located in for Cover purposes.

Covering Terrain always has a bracket (Height Y) associated with it that corresponds to the largest Height where this Terrain Feature can contribute to Cover.

For example, Fields are Covering Terrain (Height 3), which means that anything with Height 4-5 cannot claim Soft Cover from Line of Sight drawn through a Field they are in contact with.
rulebook-covering_terrain.title: Covering Terrain

rulebook-dangerous_terrain.def:
A unit must take a Dangerous Terrain Test at the end of its move if it has been in contact with a Dangerous Terrain during one the following moves: Charge Move, Failed Charge Move, March Move, Flee Move, or Pursue Move.

Dangerous Terrain Tests are performed by rolling a number of D6.

For each roll of X+, the unit suffers a hit that wounds automatically with always AP 10.

(Note: Special Saves can still be taken, and this is not an attack).

The number of dice the unit must roll is equal to half the number of models in it (rounding fractions up), multiplied by the models’ Height. If a value is given for Y, only models fulfilling these criteria take the Dangerous Terrain Test.

For example, a unit of 19 Height 1 Dwarven Warriors would roll 10 dice (19÷2 –> 10, ×1), while a unit of a single Height 5 Dragon would roll 5 dice (1÷2 –> 1, ×5).

If one of the above-mentioned moves was performed by a Unit that has been in contact with several Terrain Features that are Dangerous Terrain, every Health Pool it contains must make a Dangerous Terrain Test for each Terrain Feature with Dangerous Terrain it has been in contact with, one at a time, removing any casualties caused by the first test before calculating the number of dice that must be rolled for the next test.

If a type of model is indicated in the brackets (Y), any model not fulfilling this criteria is considered Height 0 for Dangerous Terrain Test purposes.


  • Only Health Pools that have actually been in contact with a Dangerous Terrain Feature need to roll any Dangerous Terrain Test.

  • Calculate the number of Dangerous Terrain Tests to roll for each Health Pool that has been in contact with the Terrain Feature, and roll the tests separately. The damage from each test is allocated towards the Health Pool that the test was rolled for.

For example, a unit of 10 Orc Warriors (Rank-and-File models, Height 1 ) is joined by two Orc Characters on Grunter (Height 2). If the unit moves through Dangerous Terrain in such a way that one of the Characters never touches the Terrain Feature, the Dangerous Terrain Tests are rolled in the following way: 5 dice for the Rank-and-File Health Pool (10÷2, ×1), 2 dice for the one Character that came in contact with the Terrain Feature (1÷2 –> 1, ×2), and no test for the other Character.
rulebook-dangerous_terrain.title: Dangerous Terrain

rulebook-disruptive_terrain.def: Units in contact with a Disruptive Terrain cannot claim Combat Score bonus from their number of Proper Ranks (i.e. Rank Bonus).
rulebook-disruptive_terrain.title: Disruptive Terrain

rulebook-opaque_terrain.def:
Line of Sight cannot be drawn through Opaque Terrain, but can be drawn into or out of it note that this means the Terrain Feature contributes to Hard Cover.

Models always ignore Opaque Terrain they are inside for drawing Line of Sight.
rulebook-opaque_terrain.title: Opaque Terrain

rulebook-terrain_features.def:
A Terrain Feature is a topographical area on the Battlefield that may be a mixture of Dangerous, Opaque, or Covering Terrain and may possess its own set of additional rules. Most Terrain Features follow the corresponding rules:

fields
Forestforest
hills
Impassable Terrainimpassableterrain
walls
Ruinsruins
Water Terrainwaterterrain
rulebook-terrain_features.title: Terrain Features

rulebook-the_world_of_the_9th_age.def:
The Ninth Age is a time of epic clashes and feats of arms, of legends, myths, monsters and magic. After nine long ages of strife, the many peoples and kingdoms of this high fantasy world have acquired highly developed and often spectacular methods of waging war. With so many great and terrible powers throughout the lands, the future is poised and uncertain: Everything could be decided on the outcome of a single battle.

For the reader who wishes to delve deeper into the lore of the Ninth Age, you can discover more of the wider setting in each Army Book, as well as our background-focused publications: the-ninth-age.com/the-world.

Among the various cultures, countries, and strange dominions of the world, sixteen great factions are pre-eminent. Each of these powers represents a terrifying military force. Each will attempt to dominate the Ninth Age as they are able, and each has connections that can bring it across the globe. As such, there is never any shortage of reasons for conflict and battle between these mighty armies - as your tabletop games can testify.

Few individuals have the chance to see more than a fraction of our world, with its astonishing variety of intelligent races and animal species, plants and cities, cults and wars. I have travelled from Avras to the Kingdom of Vanhu. I’ve seen Sunna’s seeds planted in Virentia and the Great Wall of Tsuandan in the far east of Augea. You could not find another who has travelled a greater distance; I have been protected by the auspice of Sunna, and here I record my knowledge on the geography of our world.
Vetia is the land of mankind, where nations of men have reigned for years under the protective sight of the Goddess and her church. There, the powerful nation of Sonnstahl guards all mankind against the dangers of the Wasteland, while to the south the merchant cities of Arcalea ply their trade with the whole of the world. There you will also find the White Mountains, impenetrable hold of the Dwarves. To the west lie the twin cities of Destria, the Kingdom of noble Equitaine, and the enchanted, emerald-green forest of Wyscan, the mysterious dwelling of the sylvan elves.
Augea, the immense sister of Vetia, separated from one another by the great Wasteland, home to the servants of the Dark Gods. Crossing east of Avras into this land, you will travel through the Barren Mountains, where the Steel Road starts its winding journey. Here is the dwelling of the Dwarves of the east, named Infernal. The Steel Road runs parallel to the Silk Road to the north, with access controlled by the Ogre Khans. It leads from the Blasted Plains through the Sky Mountains, across the northern part of the human region of Sagarikadesha, finishing its rich path in the glorious land of Tsuandan, where the Dragon Emperor rules over men.
Set sail south from Bellatorre, and in three nights you will reach the docks of Port Reynaud, Equitaine’s holdfast in Taphria. Should you dare it, you will never forget the nights spent in the Great Desert, for they are terrible and fascinating all at once. There, following the path of the Napaat river, lie the remains of a truly ancient kingdom with its legends of never-dying monstrosities. In the west stand the fortresses and souks of Qassar, full of exotic smells and tales of evil spirits, the djinn. In the west and southeast of the continent lie vast kingdoms of men; the Koghi Empire and Kingdom of Vanhu respectively. Finally in its south, the forests around the Mfumu river are said to hide some of the most ancient secrets of the world.
The Great Ocean divides Vetia from the two western continents, Silexia in the north and Virentia in the south. The Ocean itself is the dominion of elves: there the fleets of the two great nations, the Highborn and their dreaded kin, vie for supremacy. Here lies the main motherland of the Highborn Elves, the proud islands of Celeda Ablan, and Silexia where freedom is a commodity to be traded.
On the eastern coast of Virentia mankind too, has established colonies: the imperial city of Fredericksberg, and the port of Aguadulce, of Destria. Beyond them, a lush forest of wonderful colors and inconceivable dan- gers hides the secrets of ancient civilizations. Dividing Virentia from Silexia, the Shattered Sea; a rumoured maelstrom of magic and tempests, from which no vessel returns.
--From A New Atlas for the Ninth Age, by Johannes Strabo
rulebook-the_world_of_the_9th_age.title: The World of the 9th Age

rulebook-psychology.def:
Every commander must face the reality that their troops might not always obey their orders. Soldiers who lack proper military training and discipline may not be able to execute more complex field operations satisfactorily. And when you ask even the hardiest warrior to face monstrous terrors, or stand firm when their comrades perish and flee, you should be prepared for the eventuality that their resolve may falter.

In The 9th Age: Fantasy Battles, there are two types of Psychology Tests that represent a warrior’s mental state and ability to follow orders:
Command and Courage.

When a unit must perform a Command or Courage Test, roll 2D6 and compare the result with the unit’s Discipline (see Characteristic Profiles in the Definitions and Terminology chapter).

If the result is equal to or lower than the Discipline value, the test is passed. Otherwise, it is failed.

/section{command_tests}/section{courage_tests}/section{psychology_states}/section{flee_move}
rulebook-psychology.title: Psychology

rulebook-command_tests.def:
Command Tests represent a warrior’s ability to perform orderly battlefield manoeuvres and rally after a rout has begun.

Common situations where Command Tests are taken are:

  • When attempting to Redirect a Charge.
Remember that this can only be attempted once per Phase per unit.

  • When attempting to perform a Combat Reform while on the losing side, and/or when Engaged on the Flank or Rear.

  • When taking a Rally Test. See the Rally Phase chapter for details.

Common Model Rules that affect Command Tests are: Disciplined,Mindless, Commanding Presence, Unruly (see Model Rules for details).


Panic? Klepa is always cool as coocumber. What’s the secret to staying calm? Just remember: you are an honest goblin with a pure heart, nothing to hide, and lots of eemaculit alibis.
rulebook-command_tests.title: Command Tests

rulebook-courage_tests.def:
Courage Tests represent a warrior’s ability to hold their position in the face of adversity. There are two primary types of Courage Tests:

  • Panic Tests: those tests are taken immediately when triggered by some circumstances.
A unit that fails a Panic Test becomes Shaken.

  •
Break Tests: taken by units on the losing side of a Combat (see the Melee Phase chapter for details).

Common Model Rules that affect Courage Tests are: Rally Around the Flag, Commanding Presence (see Model Rules for details).

at (current page.south east)
-1
;


/subsection{panic_tests}
rulebook-courage_tests.title: Courage Tests

rulebook-panic_tests.def:
A Panic test is a type of Courage Test taken in certain situations, such as:

  • A friendly Shaken unit performs a Flee Move through the unit.

  • A Flee Move that is the direct consequence of a voluntary decision does not cause a Panic Test to friendly units.
This includes Flee Moves following a Flee! Charge Reaction (unless that reaction was caused by a failed Panic Test due to being Charged by a model with Terror, in which case it was not voluntary), and voluntary Breaking from Combat with a unit entirely with Feigned Flight.

Note that a Flee Move due to a failed Rally Test is not a voluntary Flee Move, even if it initially was.

  • Take the test after completing the Flee Move.

  • The unit suffered enough Health Point losses in a single phase from Ranged Attacks originating from enemy models to fulfil both the following criteria:

  • The unit suffered at least 3 Health Points losses, and

  • The unit suffered an amount of Health Points losses at least equal to 25% of the number of HP the unit had at the start of the Phase.

Take the Panic Test immediately after possible casualties have been removed. Ignore Health Point losses suffered while Engaged in Combat.

  • An enemy unit containing Terror declares a Charge against the unit in the Charge Phase.

Units do not take Panic Tests if:

  • They are Engaged in Combat, or

  • They are already Shaken, or

  • They already passed a Panic Test during the same phase.

If a unit fails a Panic test, it immediately becomes Shaken.
Note: this does not mean that the unit performs a Flee Move.
rulebook-panic_tests.title: Panic Tests

rulebook-psychology_states.def:
Units may suffer from various psychological states, which can limit their actions.

It is recommended to use markers to indicate the current state of each unit.

Note that units can be in multiple states simultaneously.

/subsection{decimated}/subsection{shaken}
rulebook-psychology_states.title: Psychology States

rulebook-decimated.def:
A model is Decimated when its original* unit’s current Health Points is 25% or less of its starting Health Points, as listed in the Army List.

Decimated models are removed as casualties just before they would perform a Flee Move.

* By original unit, it is meant the unit as listed on the Army List.
This means that the Rank-and-File part of a Combined Unit might be considered Decimated while an Attachable Model joined to the unit is not, or vice versa.

In this case, remove only Decimated models from the unit before performing a Flee Move, and leave models that are not Decimated on the Battlefield.
rulebook-decimated.title: Decimated

rulebook-shaken.def:
When a unit fails a Panic Test, a Break Test, or chooses the Flee! Charge Reaction, it becomes Shaken.

A Shaken unit is unable to perform voluntary actions.

This includes declaring Charges, moving in any way other than a Flee Move, shooting, generating Magic Dice, casting spells, or activating Magic Items that require a voluntary activation.
There is one exception: the unit may still choose to Flee! or Hold! as a Charge Reaction.

Remember that if unit is Shaken, it temporarily stops being Scoring. This lasts until it is no longer Shaken.

A Shaken unit that finds itself Engaged in Combat is removed as casualty at step 1 of the Round of
Combat Sequence.

In order to remember which units are Shaken, we recommend that Shaken units are clearly marked. This can either be done with specific markers or tokens to indicate a unit is Shaken, or if you do not have such markers, a commonly used method for marking Shaken units is to take one model from the front rank of the Shaken unit, and put it lying face down next to the unit.
rulebook-shaken.title: Shaken

rulebook-flee_move.def:
A Flee Move is a specific type of move performed in certain situations.

Common instances are: failing a Rally Test, choosing to Flee! as a Charge Reaction or failing a Break Test (without being caught by any Pursuing enemy unit). When making a Flee Move, follow these steps:
1 - Roll the Flee Distance (normally this is 2D6").
2 - Each Flee Move starts by Pivoting the unit to face a certain direction, determined as such:

  • Failed Rally Test: Pivot the unit to face directly away from the closest non-Shaken enemy unit.

The direction is specified by a line from Centre of unit to Centre of unit. If there are multiple enemy units at equal distances, the opponent chooses which one of its units will be used to determine the direction of the Flee Move.

  • Flee! Charge Reaction and failed Terror Tests: Pivot the unit to face directly away from the Charging enemy unit.

The direction is specified by a line from Centre of unit to Centre of unit.

  • Failed Break Test: Pivot the Shaken unit so that its Rear Facing is parallel with the Facing of the enemy it was Engaged with.

If multiple units are eligible, the opponent chooses which of their units will be used to determine the direction of the Flee Move.

3 - Move the Shaken unit straight forward by the distance rolled.
4 - A Flee Move, including the initial Pivot, ignores the Unit Spacing rule, and can move through any Obstructions.

The move still cannot end with the Fleeing unit overlapping any other unit or Impassable Terrain: continue the move in a straight line until the unit can be placed on the battlefield without overlapping any Obstructions.

Remember that the unit ignores the Unit Spacing rule, which means it can be placed within 1" of other units or Impassable Terrain.

  • If the Fleeing unit moves through any friendly unit, this unit must take a Panic Test.

  • If the Fleeing unit moves through any enemy unit or Impassable Terrain, treat these as Dangerous Terrain (4+).

5 - If the Flee Move brings the unit into contact with the Table Edge, or with an enemy unit that has declared a Charge against it during the same phase, the unit is removed as a casualty.
rulebook-flee_move.title: Flee Move

rulebook-magical_move.def:
Some spells or abilities allow a unit to perform a
Magical Move.

This move is performed as if it were the Movement Phase, following the same rules and restrictions: the unit can perform a Move Manoeuvre.

Characters and other Attachable Models can join or leave units.

Restrictions that apply during the Movement Phase (e.g. units that are Shaken or Engaged in Combat cannot perform a Move Manoeuvre) still apply.

The distance that the Magical Move can be performed is specified in the spell or ability.

The target’s Mobility is changed to always equal to the distance of the Magical Move, for the duration of the move.

For example, an effect could be: The target may perform a 6" Magical Move. This means the target can perform any normal Move Manoeuvre as if its Mobility was 6", including marching 12".

A unit can only perform a single Magical Move per Phase.
rulebook-magical_move.title: Magical Move

rulebook-recover_health_points.def:
Some spells or abilities allow units and models Recover Health Points lost during the battle.
The amount of Health Points that can be Recovered is specified in the ability.

Recovering Health Points cannot bring back models that have been removed as casualties, and cannot increase a model’s Health Points above its starting value (any excess Health Points are lost).

Attachable Models inside a combined unit cannot Recover Health Points from spells or abilities that allow a unit to Recover Health Points. Such models can only Recover Health Points when it is specified that they may.

Sometimes people say to Klepa, hey Klepa, you sold me this iron kettle that sploded first time it boiled. Or Klepa, you promised this magic amulet would fix my toenails and now all I got is nubs for feet. Or Mr Klepa, you’re under arrest for sale of rabid gnasher-dasher disguised as fluffy pet gerbil. And I say, I told you – Klepa products always work. Just sometimes they work too much. That’s traditional goblin method, you can’t per-see-coot me for my culture!
So yes, when we see foolish wizards whose spells work too much, we admire that enthusiasticity. Better to go big and learn something exciting than to be tame, boring, careful, sucks-ex-full all your life, that’s common sense.
Wizards don’t mind too much about common sense, seems like. Magic comes at a cost, they say – like Klepa merch and dice. ’Cept Klepa costs are lowest this side of Wasteland, but magic costs very high. Cast a spell wrong, it’ll turn you into a pile of cinders, or suck your soul out your nostrils. That’s what I call steep!
rulebook-recover_health_points.title: Recover Health Points

rulebook-raise_health_points.def:
Raising Health Points is similar to Recovering, with the exception that it can bring back models that have been removed as casualties.

When Raising Health Points, lost Health Points on models in the unit (excluding Attachable Models) are first Recovered, followed by bringing back models.

Each raised model must fully recovered all its Health Points before another model can be raised.

The total number of models in the unit cannot exceed its starting number; any excess raised Health Points are lost.

Raised models are placed in the Rear Rank if it is incomplete, or form a new Rear Rank if the current one is complete.

In units with only one rank, a raised model can either be placed in the Front Rank, or the player can declare the Front Rank complete and create a new rank behind it (remember that a unit cannot voluntarily have more ranks than files, unless it is wide enough to have a Proper Rank).

Any model that cannot be placed in a valid position, following the Unit Spacing rule, is lost.

Any used One use only effects or destroyed equipment are not regained.

Raised models are subject to the same ongoing effects as their unit.
rulebook-raise_health_points.title: Raise Health Points

rulebook-summoned_units.def:
Summoned units are units that are created during the game.

When Summoning a unit, all its models must be Deployed within the specified Range of the ability.

If the unit is summoned as a result of a spell with Type: Ground, at least one model must be placed on the targeted point, and all models must be within the spell’s Range.

Summoned models must be placed following the Unit Spacing rule. If the whole unit cannot be Deployed, then no model can be Deployed.

Once summoned, the newly created unit operates as a normal unit controlled by the side that Summoned it.

Summoned units do not award Victory Points to the opponent when they are removed as a casualty.
rulebook-summoned_units.title: Summoned Units

special-larger_bases.title: Larger Bases
special-larger_bases.def:
In an army with Larger Bases, models can use different base sizes from those listed in their unit entries. This is to allow people with models on slightly larger bases to play The 9th Age.

Each Unit using this option must have the new base size noted on the Army List, and all models in a unit must have the same base size.

The Base Sizes must be:

  • 100% -- 125% of the original width

  • 100% -- 150% of the original depth

  • Both width and depth must be divisible by 5mm

In addition, Attachable models with increased Base Sizes can only join Units with the same percentage increase(s) to their Base Sizes.

If the models with increased Base Size make up 25% or less of the total model count, the army suffers a penalty of -200 Victory Points at the end of the game (to a minimum of 0). Armies with more than 25% (or none at all) do not suffer this penalty.

Note: The purpose of this rule is to allow people to use models from different game systems to test out T9A or to use their particularly imposing models legally

special-properties_of_magic_items.title: Properties of Magic Items
special-properties_of_magic_items.def:
The following terms are common keywords used to describe Magic Items:

  • Category: each Magic Item belongs to a single Category, listed below. No model or unit can select more than one Magic Item from each Category.

  • Dominant: a model can only have one Dominant Magic Item, no matter its Category.

  • Legendary: all Magic Items are Legendary, unless stated otherwise.

special-who_is_affected_.title: Who is affected ?
special-who_is_affected_.def:
Unless specifically mentioned otherwise:

  • Global and Defensive Characteristic modifiers are applied only to the model part taking the Magic Item (and not to other model parts such as mounts)*.

  • Model Rules that are not Attack Attributes are applied to the combined model as a whole.

  • Offensive Characteristic modifiers and Attack Attributes are applied only to the model part bearing or wearing the item.

  • Rules and modifiers from a Weapon Enchantment are only applied to the Standard Melee Attacks made with the Enchanted Weapon.

Exceptions to the above may be noted in the item’s description, using terminology such as:

  • The wielder, wearer, bearer: these terms mean the same thing for rules purposes and refer to the model part the Magic Item was bought for, and therefore generally do not affect mounts.

  • The wielder’s model, wearer’s model, bearer’s model: these terms refer to all model parts of the model the Magic Item was bought for, including their mounts.

  • The wielder’s unit, wearer’s unit, bearer’s unit: these terms refer to all model parts in the same unit as the model the Magic Item was bought for, including mounts and the model itself.

*Characters on mounts with fixed Global or Defensive Characteristics values (i.e. any value that is not C or C+X) do not benefit from modifiers to those Characteristics.
See the Character Mounts section of the Characters chapter for examples of interactions with mounts.

special-list_of_common_and_shared_magic_.title: List of Common and Shared Magic Items
special-list_of_common_and_shared_magic_.def: Magic Items fall into one of the following categories.

special-heros_heart.title: Hero's Heart
special-heros_heart.def: +1 Att, and always at least Str 5 and AP 2.

special-giant_slayer.title: Giant Slayer
special-giant_slayer.def:
Crush Attack.
This Crush Attack gains +1 to hit towards models with Height 5.

special-king_slayer.title: King Slayer
special-king_slayer.def:
Attached, which cannot be lost.

While there is an enemy Character in contact with the wielder’s unit, the wielder gains +1 Att, +2 Str, and +2 AP.

special-vorpal_binding.title: Vorpal Binding
special-vorpal_binding.def:
Successful Armour Saves and Special Saves against

attacks made with this weapon must be rerolled.

special-destinys_call.title: Destiny’s Call
special-destinys_call.def:
Aegis(4+), and the model’s Armour is always 3.

Note that this means it cannot be improved beyond 3.
It is still affected by Armour Penetration.

special-essence_of_mithril.title: Essence of Mithril
special-essence_of_mithril.def: The wearer’s Armour is set to 5 and can never be improved beyond this.

special-dusk_forged.title: Dusk Forged
special-dusk_forged.def:
The bearer must reroll its failed Armour Saves.

The bearer automatically fails all Special Saves,
regardless of whether Using the Shield or not.

special-basalt_infusion.title: Basalt Infusion
special-basalt_infusion.def: +1 Armour, Aegis(3+, against Flaming Attacks), and the wearer automatically fails all Regeneration Saves.

special-warding_of_unity.title: Warding of Unity
special-warding_of_unity.def:
Attached, which cannot be lost, and

Resistance(Melee Attacks).

special-wild_warding.title: Wild Warding
special-wild_warding.def:
+3 Arm.

The models Armour value can never be improved beyond 5.

special-banner_of_speed.title: Banner of Speed
special-banner_of_speed.def: A unit containing one or more Banner of Speed gains +1" Charge Speed and Mobility.

special-sheltering_standard.title: Sheltering Standard
special-sheltering_standard.def:
Attacks with Armour Penetration 2 or less can never
reduce the Armour Save roll of the bearer’s unit to worse than 6+.

special-banner_of_courage.title: Banner of Courage
special-banner_of_courage.def:
The bearer’s unit may reroll failed Panic Tests.

If the Battle Standard Bearer or the General is part of the bearer’s unit, it automatically passes Panic Tests instead.

special-distortion_emblem.title: Distortion Emblem
special-distortion_emblem.def:
One use only. Duration: End of Turn.
May be activated at the start of any Phase.
The bearer’s unit gains Hard Target(2)

special-flaming_standard.title: Flaming Standard
special-flaming_standard.def:
One use only. Duration: End of Combat.
May be activated when Choosing Equipment and Abilities.
The bearer’s unit gains Flaming Attacks

special-aether_icon.title: Aether Icon
special-aether_icon.def: The bearer’s unit gains Magic Resistance(1).

special-rending_banner.title: Rending Banner
special-rending_banner.def:
One use only. Duration: End of Combat.
May be activated when Choosing Equipment and Abilities:
Rank-and-File models in the bearer’s unit gain +1 AP.

special-mask_of_mindless_violence.title: Mask of Mindless Violence
special-mask_of_mindless_violence.def:
Rage.
All Melee Attacks made by or against the wearer gain +1 to hit.

special-mimic_cloak.title: Mimic Cloak
special-mimic_cloak.def:
Stand Behind.
The wearer’s model loses Stubborn, Bodyguard, cannot gain either in any way, and is never considered to fulfil the criteria of Bodyguard.

In addition, the model cannot make any Supporting Attacks.

special-binding_scroll.title: Binding Scroll
special-binding_scroll.def:
May be activated at the end of the Siphon the Veil step during your opponent’s Magic Phase.
When activated, choose a Caster and select one of its spells (Bound or Learned): the chosen Caster cannot cast the selected instance of the spell in this Magic Phase.
E.g. if a caster has the same spell more than one time, only a single instance cannot be cast.

special-essence_of_a_free_mind.title: Essence of a Free Mind
special-essence_of_a_free_mind.def:
The bearer may choose up to two Paths on the Army List instead of one (from the ones normally available to it).

Select spells for both Paths on the Army List as normal.
During Pre-game Selections, choose which one of the two Paths to use.

The bearer cannot select Master Spells.

All effects based on the choice of Path depends upon the Path chosen in Pre-game Selections.

special-crown_of_the_wizard_king.title: Crown of the Wizard King
special-crown_of_the_wizard_king.def:
During Pre-game Selections, randomise a Magic Path (from all Paths in this book).

The bearer is a Wizard Apprentice using the
randomised Path, and may not Swap any spells.

The bearer cannot take any Magic Items nor any other upgrades that are restricted to Wizards (or any types of Wizards).

special-magical_heirloom.title: Magical Heirloom
special-magical_heirloom.def: The bearer knows the Hereditary Spell of its Army Book in addition to its other spells (it cannot select it during Spell Selection, and cannot replace or otherwise lose it).

special-talisman_of_the_void.title: Talisman of the Void
special-talisman_of_the_void.def:
Channel(1).
This item can only be used if the model’s army´s total combined Channel is 3 or less (excluding Channel from this Magic Item).

special-rod_of_battle.title: Rod of Battle
special-rod_of_battle.def: The bearer can cast Living Steel (Alchemy) as a Bound Spell(4+).

special-dragons_brew.title: Dragon’s Brew
special-dragons_brew.def: Breath Attack(Str 4, AP 1, Flaming Attacks, Stand and Shoot).

special-potion_of_power_preservation.title: Potion of Power Preservation
special-potion_of_power_preservation.def: May be used immediately when a Casting Roll or Dispel Roll fails, due to not rolling high enough: do not discard the Magic Dice used in this unsuccessful attempt.

special-scroll_of_power.title: Scroll of Power
special-scroll_of_power.def: May be used immediately after a Casting Roll: the bearer may add one additional free Magic Dice to this Casting Roll (the limit of 5 Magic Dice still applies).

special-scroll_of_draining.title: Scroll of Draining
special-scroll_of_draining.def: May be activated in the opponent’s Magic Phase, immediately after Excess Magic: the opponent immediately discards 1 Magic Dice.

special-spell_scroll.title: Spell Scroll
special-spell_scroll.def: May be activated at any time during your Magic Phase. The bearer knows the spell indicated in brackets (X) in addition to its other spells (if the bearer already knows the spell, this has no effect).

special-how_to_use_this_document.title: How to Use this Document
special-how_to_use_this_document.def: This document describes the different Paths of Magic and Special Items available for The 9th Age: Fantasy Battles and as such is to be used in conjunction with the main Rulebook. For convenience, we repeated the main rules related to spells and Magic Items from the Rulebook in the corresponding sections below, along with the information needed to read the Paths.

special-paths_of_magic.title: Paths of Magic
special-paths_of_magic.def: Spells are cast during the Magic Phase. Most spells belong to a specific Path of Magic.

special-faction_specific_spells.title: Faction Specific Spells
special-faction_specific_spells.def: Each Faction has some unique spells to cast.

special-spell_name.title: Spell Name
special-spell_name.def: Use the spell’s name to indicate which spell you want to cast.

special-casting_value.title: Casting Value
special-casting_value.def: The Casting Value (CV) is the minimum number you need to roll with Magic Dice to successfully cast the spell.

special-spell_type.title: Spell Type
special-spell_type.def:
The Spell Type specifies how the target of the spell is chosen. A spell can have one or more of the following spell Types:

  • Augment: can only target friendly units, (or friendly models within units if Focused).

  • Aura: targets all eligible targets.
For example, a spell with Augment, Aura, and Range 12" targets all friendly units within 12" of the Caster.

  • Caster: can only target the model casting the spell.

  • Damage: can only target units not Engaged in Combat.

  • Focused: can only target single models, including Attachable Models inside units. If a model consisting of multiple model parts is targeted, only one part can be chosen.

  • Ground: the spell targets a point on the Battlefield rather than units or models.

  • Hex: can only target enemy units, (enemy models within units if Focused).

  • Missile: can only target units within the Caster’s Line of Sight, and cannot be cast if the Caster is Engaged in Combat. When casting a spell with Type: Missile, check which is the Target Facing (see Shooting Phase chapter).

  • Range X": the spell has a maximum casting range. Targets must be within X" of the Caster.

  • Universal: the spell can target both friendly and enemy units (or models within units if Focused).

special-duration.title: Duration
special-duration.def: All spells have a Duration, which follows the same rule as described under Duration of Effects (see the Definitions and Terminology chapter).

special-effect.title: Effect
special-effect.def: The effect of a spell describes what happens to the target when the spell is successfully cast.

season-deployment_types.title: Deployment Types
season-deployment_types.def:
Follow the rules in the Rulebook, except where those rules are overridden by the details under each Deployment Type.

Unless mentioned otherwise, the Central Line is the line drawn through the Battlefield Centre and parallel to the Long Battlefield Edges.

1.

Deployment Zones are more than 12" away from the Central Line, and more than 6" from the Short Battlefield Edges.

2.

Player A’s Deployment Zone is more than 9" away from the Central Line, and more than 12" from the Short Battlefield Edges.

Player B’s Deployment Zone is more than 15" away from the Central Line.

The Defender also chooses if they are player A or player B.

3.

Deployment Zones are more than 15" away from the Central Line.

The table is divided along the Long Battlefield Edge into three equal areas (west, centre, east).

The Defender also chooses one of these thirds to be their Spearhead Area.

The Attacker then immediately chooses one of the remaining two thirds as their Spearhead Area.

units Deployed entirely within their Spearhead Area gain Vanguard(3").

4.

Each Deployment Zone alternates between 9" and 15" from the Central Line, as shown in the diagram.

Along with selecting a side, the Defender selects one of the two Deployment Zones. The Attacker has the other Deployment Zone.


5.

Deployment Zones are more than 9" away from the Central Line (see diagram), which is the line drawn from one corner of the Battlefield to the opposite corner.

The Defender chooses which corners to use.

6.

After choosing a side the Defender selects a Short Battlefield Edge; the Attacker has the opposite one.
Defenders Deployment Zone is more than 6" away from the Central Line, and 18" away from the Attackers Short Battlefield Edge.

Attackers Deployment Zone is instead more than 12" away from the Central Line, and 18" away from the Defenders Short Battlefield Edge.

season-recommended_army_size_and_table_s.title: Recommended Army Size and Table Size
season-recommended_army_size_and_table_s.def: Season Pack 2 is made to be played with a Field Army of 4000 points and on a 48"×72" Battlefield but can be played at both larger and smaller scale, instructions on how to adapt deployments will come in the full version.

season-selecting_terrain_map_and_deploym.title: Selecting Terrain Map and Deployment Types
season-selecting_terrain_map_and_deploym.def:
In the absence of already chosen Deployment Types and/or Terrain Maps (e.g. due to players agreeing to play particular ones, or playing in a tournament where these are already set for each game)̂, we recommend consulting the tables below:

season-trophies_of_war.title: Trophies of War
season-trophies_of_war.def:
Setup during Pre-game Selections: none.

Rules: whenever an Enemy unit Engaged in Combat, including all Attached Models, is removed as a casualty, put a single Trophy Token on a single Friendly Scoring unit that was just Engaged with the removed unit.

A unit immediately loses all its Trophy Tokens if it loses Scoring.

End of Game Completion: the player with the most Trophy Tokens on their units wins.

If both players have no Tokens and one player also has no Scoring units, remaining on the Battlefield, the other player wins.

season-divide_and_conquer.title: Divide and Conquer
season-divide_and_conquer.def:
Setup during Pre-game Selections: mark the Battlefield Centre and divide the Battlefield into quarters.
(As shown in the diagram.)

Rules: END of Game Turns 3 to 6, a player gains a single Objective Counter if they have more quarters touching Friendly Scoring units than the opponent has.

Each unit can only touch a single quarter at a time, determined by the location of its Centre.

A unit with its Centre within 9" of the Battlefield Centre does not count as being in Contact with any quarter.

End of Game Completion: the player with the most Objective Counters wins.

season-breakthrough.title: Breakthrough
season-breakthrough.def:
Setup during Pre-game Selections: mark all Scoring units on the opponent's Army List

Rules: none.

End of Game Completion: combine the number of:


  • marked Enemy units that were removed as a casualty whilst Engaged in Combat and

  • Friendly Scoring units in Contact with the Enemy's Deployment Zone.

The player with the highest total wins.

season-secure_targets.title: Secure Targets
season-secure_targets.def:
Setup during Pre-game Selections: place two markers on opposite sides of the Battlefield, with their centres on the Central Line and 18"* from the Battlefield Centre.

Rules: END of Game Turns 3 to 6, a player gains a single Objective Counter if they control more markers than their opponent.

A marker is controlled if there are any Friendly Scoring units and no Enemy Scoring units within 6" of a marker.

End of Game Completion: the player with the most Objective Counters wins.

* For Battlefields of a larger or smaller size than the standard 72"×48", replace 18" with a distance equal to a quarter of the Long Battlefield Edge.

season-hold_the_centre.title: Hold the Centre
season-hold_the_centre.def:
Setup during Pre-game Selections: mark the Battlefield Centre.

Rules: END of Game Turns 3 to 6, the player with the most Scoring units within 9" of the Battlefield Centre gains a single Objective Counter.

End of Game Completion: the player with the most Objective Counters wins.

season-skull_of_harald_redstub.title: Skull of Harald Redstub
season-skull_of_harald_redstub.def:
Setup during Pre-game Selections: place a marker on the Battlefield Centre and two markers on opposite sides of the Battlefield, with their centres on the Central Line and 18"* from the Battlefield Centre.

Then place a single Clue Token on each Terrain Feature except Impassable Terrain and playermade Terrain Features.

Rules: START of each Friendly Player Turn, pick up a Clue Token from each Terrain Feature where:


  • there is a Clue Token,

  • a Friendly Scoring unit is in Contact, and

  • no Enemy Scoring units are in Contact.

END of Game Turn 3, the player with the most Clue Token selects which marker holds the Skull.

In case of a tie, the marker at the Battlefield Centre is selected.

End of Game Completion: the player with the most Scoring units within 6" of the Skull wins.

* For Battlefields of a larger or smaller size the standard 72"x 48", replace 18" with a distance equal to a quarter of the Long Battlefield Edge.

season-settle_the_score.title: Settle the Score
season-settle_the_score.def:
Pre-game Selections: on the opponent’s Army List mark TWO Rank-and-File units.

End of Game Completion: BOTH marked units are removed as a casualty, Decimated, or Shaken.

season-demonstrate_superiority.title: Demonstrate Superiority
season-demonstrate_superiority.def:
Pre-game Selections: on the opponent’s Army List mark TWO Scoring units.

End of Game Completion: at least one of the marked units is removed as a casualty, Decimated, or Shaken.

season-slay_the_beast.title: Slay the Beast
season-slay_the_beast.def:
Setup during Pre-game Selections: on the opponent's Army List mark the TWO most expensive
Non-Scoring Rank-and-File units or Characters of Height 4-5 with Solitary.

End of Game Completion: at least one of the marked units is removed as a casualty, Decimated, or Shaken.

season-assassinate.title: Assassinate
season-assassinate.def:
Setup during Pre-game Selections: on the opponent’s Army List mark TWO Characters.

These must be: Characters who can be Deployed during Battle Setup. (Note: you cannot mark Hidden Characters.)

End of Game Completion: at least one of the marked units is removed as a casualty, Decimated, or Shaken.

season-capture_their_banners.title: Capture their Banners
season-capture_their_banners.def:
Setup during Pre-game Selections: on the opponent's Army List mark ALL Scoring units and The Battle Standard Bearer.
At least 3 units must be marked.

End of Game Completion: Three or more of the marked units are removed as a casualty, Decimated, or Shaken.

season-conserve_our_numbers.title: Conserve our Numbers
season-conserve_our_numbers.def:
Setup during Pre-game Selections: on YOUR Army List the opponent marks ALL Scoring units and The Battle Standard Bearer.

At least 3 units must be marked.

End of Game Completion: three or more of the marked units are NEITHER removed as a casualty, nor Decimated, nor Shaken.

season-determining_primary_and_secondary.title: Determining Primary and Secondary Objectives
season-determining_primary_and_secondary.def:
If the Primary Objective and/or Secondary Objectives are not already determined (e.g. due to players agreeing to play particular ones, or playing in a tournament where these are already set for each game), we recommend consulting the lists below:

season-terrain_feature_dimensions.def:
